titleStmt.title: Yarington, Robert, fl. 1601 : : Two lamentable tragedies (1601)

publicationStmt.publisher: Robert Yarington, fl. 1601 (fl.1594-1601) Two Lamentable Tragedies. The one, of the murther of Maister Beech, a Chaundler in Thames-streete, and his boye, done by Thomas Merry. The other of a young childe murthered in a Wood by two Ruffins, with the consent of his Vnckle. By Rob. Yarington London Printed for Mathew Lawe [etc.] 1601

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
Two lamentable tragedies. Genre: Tragedy. Date first published: 1601. Date first performed: 1594-1598 ?

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Homicide Avarice Pandino Pertillo Covetousness Truth Armenia Beech Merry Rachell Neighbour Sostrato Alinso Falleria Harry Williams Maid Loney 1 Ruffian Scrivener 2 Ruffian 2 Neighbour 3 Neighbour 4 Neighbour Combined voice 1 Murderer 2 Murderer Duke of Padua Turqualo Vesuvio Alberto Cowley 1 Waterman 2 Waterman Gentleman VVin. woman salesman 1 housekeeper 2 housekeeper Constable Officer 3 Watchman UNK

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Homicide
sp.l: I have in vain past through each stately street,
And blindfold turning of this happy town,
For wealth, for peace, and goodly government,
Yet can I not find out a mind, a heart
For blood and causeless death to harbour in;
They all are bent with virtuous gainful trade,
To get their needments for this mortal life,
And will not soil their well-addicted hearts:
With rape, extortion, murther, or the death,
Of friend or foe, to gain an Empery.
I cannot glut my blood delighted eye;
With mangled bodies which do gasp and groan,
Ready to pass to fair Elizium,
Nor bath my greedy hands in reeking blood,
Of fathers by their children murthered:
When all men else do weep, lament and wail,
The sad exploits of fearful tragedies,
It glads me so, that it delights my heart,
To add new torments to their bleeding smarts.
But here comes Auarice, as if he sought,
Some busy work for his pernicious thought:
Whither so fast all griping Auarice?

sp.speaker: Aua.
sp.l: Why what carest thou, I seek for one I miss.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I may supply the man you wish to have.

sp.speaker: Aua.
sp.l: Thou seems to be a bold audacious knave,
I do not like intruding company,
That seek to undermine my secrecy.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Mistrust me not I am thy faithful friend.

sp.speaker: Aua.
sp.l: Many say so, that prove false in the end.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But turn about and thou will know my face,

sp.speaker: Aua.
sp.l: It may be so, and know thy want of grace,
What Homicide thou art the man I seek:
I reconcile me thus upon thy cheek.
Hadst thou named blood and damned iniquity,
I had forborne to bight so bitterly.

sp.speaker: Hom.
sp.l: Knowest thou a heart wide open to receive,
A plot of horrid desolation,
Tell me of this, thou art my chiefest good,
And I will quaff thy health in bowls of blood.

sp.speaker: Aua.
sp.l: I know two men, that seem two innocents,
Whose looks surveyed with judicial eyes:
Would seem to bear the marks of honesty,
But snakes find harbour amongst the fairest flowers,
Then never credit outward semblances:
I know their hearts relentless merciless,
And will perform through hope of benefit:
More dreadful things than can be thought upon.

sp.speaker: Hom.
sp.l: If gain will draw, I prithee then allure,
Their hungry hearts with hope of recompense,
But tie despair unto those moving hopes,
unleased a deed of murther farther it,
Then blood on blood, shall overtake them all,
And we will make a bloody festival.

sp.speaker: Coue.
sp.l: The plots are laid, the keys of golden coin,
Hath oped the secret closets of their hearts,
Inter, insult, make captive at thy will,
Themselves, and friends, with deeds of damned ill:
Yonder is truth, she cometh to bewail,
The times and parties that we work upon.

sp.speaker: Hom.
sp.l: Why let her weep, lament, and mourn for me,
We are right bred of damned iniquity,
And will go make a twofold Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Truth.
sp.l: Go you disturbers of a quiet soul,
Sad, greedy, gaping, hungry Cannibals,
That joy to practise others miseries:
Gentles, prepare your tear bedecked eyes,
To see two shows of lamentation,
Besprinkled everywhere with guiltless blood,
Of harmless youth, and pretty innocents,
Our Stage doth wear habiliments of woe,
Truth rues to tell the truth of these laments:
The one was done in famous London late,
Within that street whose side the river Thames
Doth strive to wash from all impurity:
But yet that silver stream can never wash,
The sad remembrance of that cursed deed,
Performed by cruel Merry on just Beech,
And his true boy poor Thomas Winchester,
The most here present, know this to be true:
Would truth were false, so this were but a tale,
The other further off, but yet too near,
To those that felt and did the cruelty:
Near Padua this wicked deed was done,
By a false Uncle, on his brothers son,
Left to his careful education,
By dying Parents, with as strict a charge,
As ever yet death-breathing brother gave:
Look for no mirth, unless you take delight,
In mangled bodies, and in gaping wounds,
Bloodily made by mercy wanting hands,
Truth will not fain, but yet doth grieve to show,
This deed of ruth and miserable woe.
I live in mean and discontented state,
But wherefore should I think of discontent:
I am beloved, I have a pretty house,
A loving sister, and a careful man,
That do not think their days work well at end,
Except it bring me in some benefit:
And well frequented is my little house,
With many guests and honest passengers,
Which may in time advance my humble state,
To greater wealth and reputation.
And here comes friends to drink some beer or ale,
They are my neighbours, they shall have the best,

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Come neighbour Beech let us have our mornings draught
And we will go drink it at young Merries house:
They say he hath the best in all this town,
Besides they say he is an honest man,
And keeps good rule and orders in his house.

sp.speaker: Beech.
sp.l: He is so indeed, his conversation,
Is full of honest harmless courtesy:
I dare presume, if that he be within,
He will serve us well, and keep us company,
See where he is, go in, I will follow you.
Nay strain no courtesy you shall go before.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You are welcome neighbour, you are welcome sir,
I pray sit down, you are very welcome both:

sp.speaker: Beech.
sp.l: We thank you for it, and we think no less,
Now fill two cans of your old strongest beer:
That make so many loose their little wits,
And make indentures as they go along.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Ho sister Rachell:

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: I come presently.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Go draw these gentlemen two Cans of beer,
Your negligence that cannot tend the shop,
Will make our customers forsake the house.
Where is Harry Williams that he stays not here.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Myself was busy dressing up the house,
As for your man he is not very well:
But sitteth sleeping by the kitchen fire.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: If you are busy get you up again,
I will draw my neighbours then their drink myself,
I will warrant you as good as any man's,
And yet no better, many have the like.

sp.speaker: Neigh.
sp.l: This shows him for a plain and honest man,
That will not flatter with too many words:
Some shrill-tongued fellows would have cogged and feigned,
Saying I will draw the best in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Beech.
sp.l: He is none of those, but bears an honest mind,
And shames to utter what he cannot prove.
But here he comes, is that the best you have,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: It is the best upon mine honest word.

sp.speaker: Beech.
sp.l: Then drink to us.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I drink unto you both.

sp.speaker: Nei., Beech.
sp.l: We pledge you both, and thank you heartily.

sp.speaker: Beech.
sp.l: Here is to you sir.

sp.speaker: Neigh.
sp.l: I thank you,

sp.speaker: Neigh.
sp.l: It is good indeed and I had rather drink,
Such beer as this as any Gascoine wine:
But it is our English manner to affect
Strange things, and price them at a greater rate,
Than home-bred things of better consequence.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: It is true indeed, if all were of your mind,
My poor estate would sooner be advanced:
And our French Merchants seek some other trade.

sp.speaker: Beech.
sp.l: Your poor estate, nay neighbour say not so,
For God be thanked you are well to live.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Not so good neighbour, but a poor young man,
That would live better if I had the means:
But as I am, I can content myself,
Till God amend my poor ability.

sp.speaker: Neigh.
sp.l: In time no doubt, why man you are but young,
And God assure yourself hath wealth in store,
If you await his will with patience.

sp.speaker: Beech.
sp.l: Thanks be to God I live contentedly,
And yet I cannot boast of mighty wealth:
But yet Gods blessings have been infinite,
And far beyond my expectations,
My shop is stored, I am not much in debt;
And here I speak it where I may be bold,
I have a score of pounds to help my need,
If God should stretch his hand to visit me,
With sickness, or such like adversity.

sp.speaker: Neigh.
sp.l: Enough for this, now neighbour what is to pay,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Two pence good sir.

sp.speaker: Beech.
sp.l: Nay pray sir forbear,
I will pay this reckoning for it is but small.

sp.speaker: Neigh.
sp.l: I will not strive since ye will have it so.

sp.speaker: Beech.
sp.l: Neighbour farewell.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Farewell unto you both.
His shop is stored he is not much in debt.
He hath a score of pounds to help his need,
Aye and a score too if the trueth were known:
I would I had a shop so stored with wares,
And forty pounds to buy a bargain with,
When as occasion should be offered me,
I would live as merry as the wealthiest man;
That hath his being within London walls,
I cannot buy my beer, my bread, my meat:
My faggots, coals, and such like necessaries,
At the best hand, because I want the coin,
That many misers coffer up in bags,
Having enough to serve their turns besides:
Ah for a trick to make this Beeches trash,
Forsake his coffer and to rest in mine,
Aye marry sir, how may that trick be done:
Marry with ease and great facility,
I will invent some new-found stratagem,
To bring his coin to my possession;
What though his death relieve my poverty,
Gain waits on courage, loss on cowardice.

body.stage: Enter Pandino and Armenia sicke on a bed, Pertillo their sonne, Falleria his brother, Sostrato his wife, Alinso their sonne, and a Scriuener with a VVill, etc.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Brother and sister, pray you both draw near,
And hear my will, which you have promised
Shall be performed with wished providence,
This little Orphan I must leave behind,
By your direction to be governed.
As for my wife and I, we do await,
The blessed hour when it shall please the Lord,
To take us to the just Jerusalem.
Our chiefest care is for that tender boy,
Which we should leave discomfortless behind,
But that we do assure us of your love,
And care to guide his weak unable youth,
In paths of knowledge grace and godliness:
As for the riches of this mortal life,
We leave enough four hundredth pounds a year,
Besides two thousand pounds to make a stock,
In money, Jewels, Plate, and household stuff,
Which yearly rents and goods we leave to you,
To be surrendered into his hands,
When he attains to years of discretion.
My Will imports thus much, which you shall hear,
And you shall be my sole Executor.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Brother and sister how my heart laments,
To see your weak and sick afflicted limbs,
Near overcome with direful maladies,
The God of heaven can truly testify,
Which to speak plain, is never a whit at all.
Which knows the secret corners of my heart,
But for the care you do impose on me,
For the tuition of your little son,
Think my kind brother, I will meditate,
Both day and night, how I may best fulfil,
The care and trust, reposed in your Will,
And see him posted quickly after you.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Enough kind brother, we assure us so,
Else would we seek another friend abroad,
To do our wills and dying Testament,
Nature and love will have a double care,
To bring him up with careful diligence,
As best beseems one of such parentage.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Assure yourself the safest course I can,
Shall be provided for your little son,
He shall be sent unto the King of heaven.

sp.speaker: Sostr.
sp.l: Fear not good brother, and my loving sister,
But we will have as tender care of him,
As if he were our own ten thousand times:
God will be father of the fatherless,
And keep him from all care and wretchedness.

sp.speaker: Allenso.
sp.l: Uncle and Aunt take comfort, I will see,
My little cousin have no injury.

sp.speaker: Pan., Ar.
sp.l: We thank you all, come let the Will be read.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: If it were sealed, I would you both were dead.

sp.speaker: Scriue.
sp.l: Then give attention, I will read the Will.

l.emph: In the name of God, Amen. I, etc.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Thus if my son miscarry, my dear brother,
You and your son shall then enjoy the land,
And all the goods which he should have possessed,

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: If he miscarry, brother God forbid,
God bless mine Nephew, that thine eyes may see,
Thy children's children with prosperity:
I had rather see the little urchin hanged,
Than he should live, and I forgo the land.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thanks gentle brother, husband seal the Will.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Give me a Pen and Ink, first to subscribe,
I write so ill through very feebleness,
That I can scarcely know this hand for mine,
But that you all can witness that it is.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: Give me the seal: I pray sir take it off,
This you deliver for your latest Will,
And do confirm it for your Testament.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: With all my heart: here brother keep my Will,
And I refer me to the will of God,
Praying him deal as well with you and yours,
As you no doubt will deal with my poor child:
Come my Pertillo, let me bless thee boy,
And lay my half dead hand upon thy head,
God grant those days that are cut off in me,
With joy and peace may multiply in thee:
Be slow to wrath, obey thy Uncle still,
Submit thyself unto Gods holy will,
In deed and word, see thou be ever true,
So brother, child, and kinsfolks all adieu.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Ah my dear mother, is my father dead?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Aye my sweet Boy, his soul to heaven is fled,
But I shall after him immediately,
Then take my latest blessing ere I die,
Come let me kiss thy little tender lips,
Cold death hath taken possession of thy mother.
Let me embrace thee in my dying arms,
And pray the lord protect thee from all harms:
Brother, I fear, this child when I am gone,
Will have great cause of grief and hideous fear:
You will protect him, but I prophecy,
His share will be of woe and misery:
But mothers fears do make these cares arise,
Come boy and close thy mothers dying eyes.
Brother and sister, here the latest words,
That your dead sister leaves for memory:
If you deal ill with this distressed boy,
God will revenge poor orphan's injuries,
If you deal well, as I do hope you will,
God will defend both you and yours from ill.
Farewell, farewell, now let me breath my last,
Into his dearest mouth, that wanteth breath,
And as we loved in life embrace in death;
Brother and sister this is all I pray,
Tender my Boy when we are laid in clay.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Gods holy Angel guide your loving souls,
Unto a place of endless happiness.

sp.speaker: Sostr.
sp.l: Amen, Amen, ah what a care she had,
Of her small Orphan, she did dying pray,
To love her child, when she was laid in clay.

sp.speaker: Scr.
sp.l: Ah blame her not although she held it dear,
She left him young the greater cause of fear.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Knew she my mind, it would recall her life,
And like a staring Comet she would move,
Our hearts to think of desolation,
Scriuenor, have you certified the will?

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Then there is two Ducats for your pains.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.l: Thanks gentle sir, and for this time farewell.

sp.speaker: Sost.
sp.l: Come pretty cousin, cozened by grim death,
Of thy most careful parents all too soon,
Weep not sweet boy, thou shalt have cause to say,
Thy Aunt was kind, though parents lie in clay.

sp.speaker: Pert.
sp.l: But give me leave first to lament the loss,
Of my dear Parents, nature bindeth me,
To wail the death of those that gave me life,
And if I live until I be a man,
I will erect a sumptuous monument,
And leave remembrance to ensuing times,
Of kind Pandino and Armenia.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: That shall not need, my father will erect,
That sad memorial of their timeless death,
And at that tomb we will lament and say
Soft lie the bones of fair Armenia.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Surcease Allenso, that is a bootless cost,
The Will imports no such injunction:
I will not spend my little Nephews wealth,
In such vain toys, they shall have funeral,
But with no stately ceremonial pomp,
that is good for nought but fools to gaze upon;
Live thou in hope to have thine uncles land.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: His land, why father you have land enough,
And more by much than I do know to use:
I would his virtues would in me survive,
So should my Uncle seem in me alive,
But to your will I do submit myself,
Do what you please concerning funerals.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Come then away, that we may take in hand,
To have possession of my brothers land,
His goods and all until he come of age:
To rule and govern such possessions.
That shall be never or I will miss my mark,
Till I surrender up my life to death:
And then my son shall be his fathers heir,
And mount aloft to honours happy chair.

sp.speaker: Merry
sp.l: Beech hath a score of pounds to help his need,
And I may starve ere he will lend it me:
But in despite I will have it ere I sleep,
Although I send him to eternal rest,
But shallow fool, thou talkest of mighty things,
And canst not compass what thou dost conceive:
Stay let me see, I will fetch him to my house,
And in my garret quickly murther him:
The night conceals all in her pitchy cloak,
And none can open what I mean to hide,
But then his boy will say I fetched him forth:
I am resolved, he shall be murthered too,
This tool shall write, subscribe, and seal their death,
And send them safely to another world:
But then my sister, and my man at home,
Will not conceal it when the deed is done,
Tush one for love, the other for reward,
Will never tell the world my close intent,
My conscience saith it is a damned deed:
To train one forth, and slay him privily,
Peace conscience, peace, thou art too scrupulous,
Gain doth attended this resolution,
Hence dastard fear, I must, I can, I will,
Kill my best friend to get a bag of gold:
They shall die both, had they a thousand lives,
And therefore I will place this hammer here,
And take it as I follow Beech up stairs,
That suddenly before he is aware,
I may with blows dash out his hateful brains,
Ho Rachell, bring my cloak, look to the house,
I will return again immediately.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Here it is brother, I pray you stay not long,
Guess will come in, it is almost supper time.

body.stage: Then Merry must passe to Beeches shoppe, who must sit in his shop, and Winchester his boy stand by: Beech reading.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Let others sup, I will make a bloodier feast,
Than ever yet was dressed in Merryes house,
Be like thyself, then have a merry heart,
Thou shalt have gold to mend thy poverty,
And after this, live ever wealthily.
What neighbour Beech, so godly occupied?

sp.speaker: Beech.
sp.l: Aye master Merry it were better read,
Than meditate on idle fantasies.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You speak the trueth: there is a friend or two
Of yours, making merry in my house,
And would desire to have your company.

sp.speaker: Beech.
sp.l: Know you their names?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No truly nor the men.
I never stood to question them of that,
But they desire your presence earnestly.

sp.speaker: Beech.
sp.l: I pray you tell them that I cannot come,
It is supper time, and many will resort,
For ware at this time, above all other times;
It is Friday night besides, and Bartholmew eve,
Therefore good neighbour make my just excuse.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: In trueth they told me that you should not stay,
Go but to drink, you may come quick again,
But not and if my hand and hammer hold.

sp.speaker: Beech.
sp.l: I am unwilling, but I do not care,
And if I go to see the company.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Come quickly then, they think we stay too long,

sp.speaker: Beech.
sp.l: I will cut a piece of Cheese to drink withal.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I take the farewell of your cutting knife,
Here is a hand shall help to cut your throat:
And give myself a fairing from your chest:
What are you ready will you go along?

sp.speaker: Beech.
sp.l: I now I am, boy look you tend the shop,
If any ask, come for me to the Bull:
I wonder who they are that ask for me.

body.stage: Then being in the vpper Rome Merry strickes him in the head fifteene times.
Merry wiped his face from blood.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I know not that, you shall see presently,
Go up those stairs, your friends do stay above,
Here is that friend shall shake you by the head,
And make you stagger ere he speak to you.
Now you are safe, I would the boy were so,
But wherefore wish I, for he shall not live,
For if he do, I shall not live myself.
Let us see what money he hath in his purse,
Mass here is ten groats, here is something for my pain,
But I must be rewarded better yet.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Who was it Rachell that went up the stairs?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: It was my brother, and a little man
Of black complexion, but I know him not.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Why do you not then carry up a light,
But suffer them to tarry in the dark.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: I had forgot, but I will bear one up.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Do so I prithee, he will chide anon.

sp.speaker: Rachell.
sp.l: O brother, brother, what have you done?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why murdered one that would have murdered me.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: We are undone, brother we are undone,
What shall I say for we are quite undone.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Quiet thyself sister, all shall be well,
But see in any case you do not tell,
This deed to Williams nor to anyone:

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: No, no, I will not, was it not master Beech?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: It was, it is, and I will kill his man,
Or in attempting do the best I can.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: What was the matter that you cried so loud?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: I must not tell you, but we are undone:

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.l: You must not tell me, but we are undone,
I will know the cause wherefore we are undone.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: O would the thing were but to do again,
The thought thereof doth rent my heart in twain,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: O master, master, what have you done?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why slain a knave that would have murdered me.
Better to kill, than to be killed myself.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: With what? where with? how have you slain the man?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why with this hammer I knocked out his brains.

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: O it was beastly so to butcher him,
If any quarrel were betwixt him and you:
You should have bad him meet you in the field,
Not like a coward under your own roof;
To knock him down as he had been an ox,
Or silly sheep prepared for slaughter house:
The Lord is just, and will revenge his blood,
On you and yours for this extremity.
I will not stay an hour within your house,
It is the wickedest deed that ever was done.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O sir content yourself, all shall be well,
What is done already, cannot be undone.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: O would to God, the deed were now to do,
And I were privy to your ill intent,
You should not do it then for all the world.
But prithee Harry do not leave the house,
For then suspicion will arise thereof
And if the thing be known we are undone

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: Forsake the house, I will not stay all night,
Though you will give the wealth of Christendom.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But yet conceal it, for the love of God,
If otherwise, I know not what to do.

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: Here is my hand, I will never utter it,
Assure yourself of that, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But swear to me, as God shall help thy soul,
Thou wilt not tell it unto anyone.

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: I will not swear, but take my honest word,
And so farewell, my soul assureth me,
God will revenge this damned iniquity.
What shall become of me unhappy wretch?
I dare not lodge within my Masters house,
For fear his murderous hand should kill me too,
I will go walk and wander up and down,
And seek some rest, until the day appear:
At the Three-Cranes, in some Hay loft I will lie,
And wail my Masters coming misery.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I have possession of my brothers goods,
His tenants pay me rent, acknowledge me
To be their Landlord, they frequent my house,
With Turkeys, Capons, Pigeons, Pigs and Geese,
And all to gain my favour and good will.
His plate, his Jewels, hangings, household stuff,
May well beseem to fit a demi King,
His stately buildings, his delightful walks,
His fertile Meadows, and rich ploughed lands,
His well grown woods and stored Fishing ponds,
Brings endless wealth, besides continual help,
To keep a good and hospitable house:
And shall I joy these pleasures but a time,
Nay brother, sister, all shall pardon me,
Before I will sell myself to penury.
The world doth know, thy brother but resigned,
The lands and goods, until his son attained,
To riper years to weld and govern them,
Then openly thou canst not do him wrong,
He living: there is the burthen of the song.
Call it a burthen, for it seems so great
And heavy burthen, that the boy should live,
And thrust me from this height of happiness:
That I will not endure so heavy weight,
But shake it off, and live at liberty,
Free from the yoke of such subjection,
The boy shall die, were he my fathers son,
Before I will part with my possession.
I will call my son, and ask his good advice,
How I may best dispatch this serious cause:
Ho sir Allenso?

sp.speaker: Alle.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Hearken son,
I must entreat your furtherance and advise,
About a thing that doth concern us near,
First tell me how thou doest affect in heart,
Little Pertillo, thy dead Uncles son.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: So well good father, that I cannot tell,
Whether I love him dearer than myself:
And yet if that my heart were called to count,
I think it would surrender me to death,
Ere young Pertillo should sustain a wrong.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: How got his safety such a deep regard
Within your heart, that you affect it so?

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Nature gave root, love, and the dying charge,
Of his dead father, gives such store of sap,
Unto this tree of my affection,
That it will never wither till I die.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: But nature, love, and reason, tells thee thus,
Thyself must yet be nearest to thyself.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: His love doth not estrange me from myself,
But doth confirm my strength with multitudes,
Of benefits, his love will yield to me.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Beware to foster such pernicious snakes,
Within thy bosom, which will poison thee.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: He is a Dove, a child, an innocent,
And cannot poison, father though he would.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I will be plainer, know Pertillos life,
Which thou dost call, a Dove, an innocent:
A harmless child, and, and I know not what,
Will harm thee more, than any Serpent can,
Aye, than the very sight of Basilisks.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Father, you tell me of a strange discourse,
How can his life produce such detriment,
As Basilisks, whose only sight is death?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Hearken to me, and I will tell thee how:
Thou knowest his fathers goods, his houses, lands,
Have much advanced our reputation,
In having but their usage for a time,
If the boy live, then like to senseless beasts,
Like longed eared Asses, and rich laden Mules,
We must resign these treasures to a boy,
And we like Asses feed on simple Hay:
Make him away, they shall continue ours,
By virtue of his fathers Testament,
The Jewels, castles, meadows, houses, lands,
Which thy small cozen, should defeat thee of,
Be still thine own, and thou advance thyself,
Above the height of all thine Ancestors.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: But if I mount by murther and deceit,
Justice will thrust aspiring thoughts below,
And make me caper for to break my neck:
After some woeful lamentation,
Of my obedience to unlawfulness:
I tell you plain, I would not have him die,
Might I enjoy the Soldans Empery.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: What wilt thou bar thyself of happiness,
Stop the large stream of pleasures which would flow,
And still attend on thee like Serving-men:
Prefer the life of him that loves thee not,
Before thine own, and my felicity.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: I would rather choose to feed on carefulness,
To ditch, to delve, and labour for my bread,
Nay rather choose to beg from door to door,
Than condescend to offer violence,
To young Pertillo in his innocence,
I know you speak, to sound what mighty share,
Pertillo hath in my affection.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: In faith I do not, therefore prithee say,
Will thou consent to have him made away.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Why then in faith, I am ashamed to think,
I had my being from so foul a lump
Of adulation and unthankfulness,
Ah, had their dying prayers no avail
Within your heart? no, damned extortion,
Hath left no room for grace to harbour in,
Audacious sin, how canst thou make him say,
Consent to make my brothers son away.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Nay if you gin to brawl, withdraw yourself,
But utter not the motion that I made,
As you love me, or do regard your life.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: And as you love my safety, and your soul,
Let grace, and fear of God, such thoughts control.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Still prattling, let your grace and fear alone,
And leave me quickly to my private thoughts,
Or with my sword I will open wide a gate,
For wrath and bloody death to enter in.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Better you gave me death and burial,
Than such foul deeds should overthrow us all.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Still are you wagging that rebellious tongue,
I will dig it out for Crows to feed upon,
If thou continue longer in my sight.
He loves him better than he loves his life,
Here is repetition of my brothers care,
Of sisters charge, of grace, and fear of God,
Fear dastards, cowards, faint heart run-aways,
I will fear no colours to obtain my will,
Though all the fiends in hell were opposite,
I would rather loose mine eye, my hand, my foot,
Be blind, want senses, and be ever lame,
Than be tormented with such discontent,
This resignation would afflict me with,
Be blithe my boy, thy life shall sure be done,
Before the setting of the morrow sun.

sp.speaker: Hom.
sp.l: Make haste, run headlong to destruction,
I like thy temper, that canst change a heart,
From yielding flesh, to Flint and Adamant,
Thou hittest it home, where thou dost fasten hold,
Nothing can separate the love of gold.

sp.speaker: Aua.
sp.l: Fear no relenting, I dare pawn my soul,
(And that is no gauge, it is the devils due)
He shall imbrue his greedy griping hands,
In the dead bosom of the bloody boy,
And wind himself, his son, and harmless wife,
In endless folds of sure destruction.
Now Homicide, thy looks are like thyself,
For blood, and death, are thy companions,
Let my confounding plots but go before,
And thou shalt wade up to the chin in gore.

sp.speaker: Homi.
sp.l: I find it true, for where thou art let in,
There is no scruple made of any sin,
The world may see thou art the root of ill,
For but for thee, poor Beech had lived still.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: O my dear brother, what a heap of woe,
Your rashness hath poured down upon your head:
Where shall we hide this trumpet of your shame,
This timeless ugly map of cruelty?
Brother, if Williams do reveal the truth,
Then brother, then, begins our scene of ruth.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I fear not Williams but I fear the boy,
Who knew I fetched his master to my house.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: What doth the boy know whereabouts you dwell?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Aye that torments me worse than pangs of hell,
He must be slain too, else he will utter all.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Hark brother, hark, methinks I hear one call.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Go down and see, pray God my man keep close:
If he prove long tongued then my days are done,
The boy must die, there is no help at all:
For on his life, my very life depends,
Besides I cannot compass what I would,
Unless the boy be quickly made away,
This that abridged his hapless masters days,
Shall leave such sound memorials one his head,
That he shall quite forget who did him harm,
Or trained his master to this bloody feast:
Why how now Rachell? who did call below?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: A maid that came to have a penny loaf.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I would a penny loaf cost me a pound,
Provided Beeches boy had eat his last.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Perchance the boy doth not remember you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: It may be so, but I will remember him.
And send him quickly with a bloody scroll,
To greet his master in another world.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: I will go to Beeches on a feigned excuse,
To see if he will ask me for his master.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No, get you up, you shall not stir abroad,
And when I call, come quickly to the door.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Brother, or that, or anything beside,
To please your mind, or ease your misery.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I am knee deep, I will wade up to the waist,
To end my heart of fear, and to attain,
The hoped end of my intention?
But I may see, if I have eyes to see,
And if my understanding be not blind,
How many dangers do already weight,
Upon my steppes of bold security,
Williams is fled, perchance to utter all,
That is but perchance, nay rather flatly no,
But should he tell, I can but die a death,
Should he conceal, the boy would utter it,
The boy must die, there is no remedy.

body.stage: The boy sitting at his maisters dore.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.l: I wonder that my master stays so long,
He had not wont to be abroad so late:
Yonder comes one, I think that same is he.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I see the boy sits at his masters door,
Or now, or never, Merry stir thyself,
And rid thy heart from fear and jealousy:
Thomas Winchester go quickly to your shop,
What sit you still, your master is at hand.

body.stage: When the boy goeth into the shoppe Merry striketh six blowes on his head and with the seauenth leaues the hammer sticking in his head, the boy groaning must be heard by a maide who must crye to her maister.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.l: O God I think there is thieves in Beeches shop.

body.stage: Enter one in his shirt and a maide, and comming to Beeches shop findes the boy murthered.

sp.speaker: Nei.
sp.l: What cruel hand hath done so foul a deed,
Thus to bemangle a distressed youth:
Without all pity or a due remorse,
See how the hammer sticketh in his head,
Wherewith this honest youth is done to death,
Speak honest Thomas, if any speech remain,
What cruel hand hath done this villainy:
He cannot speak, his senses are bereft,
Ho neighbour Loney, pray come down with speed,
Your tenant Beeches man is murthered.
What would you have some Mustard?

sp.speaker: Nei.
sp.l: Your tenant Beeches man, is murthered.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Whose smothered, I think you lack your wit,
What neighbour? what make you here so late?

sp.speaker: Nei.
sp.l: I was affrighted by a sudden cry,
And coming down found master Beeches man,
Thus with a hammer sticking in his head.

sp.speaker: Loney.
sp.l: Ah woe is me for Thomas Winchester,
The truest soul that ever master had,
Where is master Beech?

sp.speaker: Neigh.
sp.l: Nay, nobody can tell:
Did you see any running from the door,
When you looked out and heard the young man cry,

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Yes I saw two truly to my thinking, but they
Ran away as fast as their hands could bear them:
By my troth it was so dark I could see nobody,
Pray God master Beech hath not hurt his boy in his patience
And if he have he must be hanged in his choler.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I dare be sworn he would not strike him thus,
Pray God his master be not slain himself.
The night grows late, and we will have this course
Be watched all night, tomorrow we shall see,
Whence sprang this strange uncivil cruelty.

sp.speaker: Nei.
sp.l: Neighbour good night.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Neighbours all good night.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Pray God I never see so sad a sight.

body.stage: Enter Merry knocking at the doore, and Rachell comes downe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: O sister, sister, now I am pursued,
The mighty clamour that the boy did make,
Hath raised the neighbours round about the street:
So that I know not where to hide myself.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: What brother, have you killed Beeches boy?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No, no, not I, but yet another hath,
Come, come to bed, for fear we be descried:
The fearfullest night that ever Merry knew.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Seem it not strange resolved gentleman,
That I thus privately have severed you,
To open secret sorrows of my heart:
Think not I do intend to undermine,
Your passed lives, although you know I am,
A man to whom the true unpartial sword,
Of equal justice is delivered,
Therefore swear both, as you respect your souls,
At the last dreadful sessions held in heaven,
First to conceal, and next to execute,
What I reveal, and shall enjoin you to.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: So you reward us, whatsoever it be,
We vow performance, and true secrecy.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: There go aside, ye seeming semblances,
Of equal justice, and true piety,
And lay my hearts corrupted Citadel,
Wide open to your thoughts to look into.
Know I am named Fallerio, to deceive
The world with show of truth and honesty,
But yet nor truth, nor honesty abides,
Within my thoughts, but falsehood, cruelty,
Blood sucking Auarice, and all the sins,
That hale men on to bloody stratagems,
Like to yourselves, which care not how you gain,
By blood, extortion, falsehood, perjury,
So you may have a pleasing recompense:
Start not aside, depart not from yourselves,
I know your composition is as mine,
Of blood, extortion, falsehood, perjury,
True branded with the mark of wickedness.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruffin.
sp.l: Be not so bitter, we are they indeed,
That would deprive our fathers of their lives,
So we were sure to have a benefit:
I way no more the murdering of a child,
Dragged from the sucking bosom of his mother,
Than I respect to quaff a bowl of wine,
Unto his health, that dearly loveth me.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruff.
sp.l: Where gold rewardeth, were apparent death
Before mine eyes, bold, hearty, visible,
I would wrestle with him for a deadly fall,
Or I would loose my guerdon promised:
I would hang my brother for to wear his coat,
That all that saw me might have cause to say,
There is a heart more firm than Adamant,
To practise execrable butcheries.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I know that well for were I not assured,
Of your performance in this enterprise,
I would not ope the closet of my breast,
To let you know my close intention,
There is a little boy, an urchin lad,
That stands between me and the glorious rays,
Of my sole-wishing sun of happiness:
There is a thicket ten miles from this place,
Whose secret ambush, and unused ways,
Doth seem to join with our conspiracy,
There murther him, and when the deed is done,
Cast his dead body in some dirty ditch,
And leave him for the Fowls to feed upon:
Do this, here is two hundredth marks in gold,
To hearten on your resolution:
Two hundredth more, after the deed is done,
I will pay you more for satisfaction.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruff.
sp.l: 'Swounds here is rewards would make one kill himself,
To leave his progeny so rich a prize,
Were twenty lives engaged for this coin,
I would end them all, to have the money mine.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruff.
sp.l: Who would not hazard life, nay soul and all,
For such a frank and bounteous pay-moister,
'sblood, what labour is it to kill a boy,
It is but thus, and then the task is done,
It grieves me most, that when this task is past,
I have no more to occupy myself,
Two hundredth marks to give a paltry stab,
I am impatient till I see the brat.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: That must be done with cunning secrecy,
I have devised to send the boy abroad,
With this excuse, to have him fostered,
In better manners than this place affords,
My wife, though loath indeed to part with him,
Yet for his good, she will forgo her joy,
With hope in time to have more firm delights,
Which she expects from young Pertillos life.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruff.
sp.l: Call you him Pertillo, faith leave out the T.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Why so?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Because Perillo will remain,
For he shall surely perish if I live:
What do you call the father of the child?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Why man, he hath no father left alive.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruff.
sp.l: Yes such a father, that doth see and know,
How we do plot this little infants woe.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruff.
sp.l: Why then his little son is much to blame,
That doth not keep his father company.
When shall we have delivery of the boy?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Tomorrow morning by the break of day,
And you must swear you will see him safely brought,
Unto the place that I do send him to.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruff.
sp.l: That may we safely, for you mean to send
Him to the wood, and there his journey ends:
Both soul and limbs shall have a place to rest,
In earth the last, the first in Abrams breast.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Come gentlemen, this night go rest with me,
Tomorrow end Pertillos tragedy.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sister, now all my gold expected hopes,
Of future good, is plainly vanished,
And in her stead, grim visaged despair,
Hath taken possession of my guilty heart,
Desire to gain, began this desperate act,
Now plain appearance of destruction,
Of soul and body, weights upon my sin,
Although we hide our sins from mortal men,
Whose glass of knowledge is the face of man,
The eye of heaven beholds our wickedness,
And will no doubt revenge the innocent.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Ah, do not so disconsolate yourself,
Nor add new streams of sorrow to your grief,
Which like a spring tide over-swells the banks,
Lest you do make an inundation,
And so be borne away with swiftest tides,
Of ugly fear, and strong despairing thoughts,
I am your sister, though a silly Maid,
I will be your true and faithful comforter.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Rachel, I see thy love is infinite,
And sorrow had so borne my thoughts away,
That I had almost quite forgot myself,
Help me dear sister to convey from hence,
The spectacle of inhumanity.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Whether would you convey this lump of dust,
Untimely murdered by your luckless hand.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: To the low room, where we will cover it,
With Faggots, tell the evening do approach:
In the mean time I will bethink myself,
How I may best convey it forth of doors,
For if we keep it longer in the house,
The savour will be felt throughout the street,
Which will betray us to destruction.
O what a horror brings this beastliness,
This chief of sins, this self accusing crime
Of murther: now I shame to know myself,
That am estranged so much from that I was,
True, harmless, honest, full of courtesy,
Now false, deceitful, full of injury:
Hold thou his heels, I will bear his wounded head,
Would he did live, so I myself were dead.

body.stage: Bring downe the body, and couer it ouer with Faggots, himselfe.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Those little sticks, do hide the murdered course,
But sticks, nor aught besides, can hide the sin:
He sits on high, whose quick all seeing eye,
Cannot be blinded by man's subtleties.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Look everywhere, can you discern him now?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Not with mine eye, but with my heart I can.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That is because thou knowest I laid him there,
To guiltiness each thought be getteth fear:
But go my true, though woeful comforter,
Wipe up the blood in every place above,
So that no drop be found about the house,
I know all houses will be searched anon:
Then burn the clothes, with which you wipe the ground
That no apparent sign of blood be found.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: I will, I will, O would to God I could,
As clearly wash your conscience from the deed,
As I can cleanse the house from least suspect,
Of murderous deed, and beastly cruelty.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Cease to wish vainly, let us seek to save,
Our names, our fames, our lives, and all we have.

body.stage: Enter three or foure neighbours together.

sp.speaker: 1. Neigh.
sp.l: Neighbours, it is bruited all about the town,
That Robert Beech a honest Chandler,
Had his man deadly wounded yester night,
At twelve a clock, when all men were asleep.
Where was his master, when the deed was done.
No man can tell, for he is missing too,
Some men suspect that he hath done the fact,
And that for fear the man is fled away,
Others, that knew his honest harmless life,
Fear that himself is likewise made away.
Then let commandment everywhere be given,
That sinks and gutters, privies, crevices,
And every place, where blood may be concealed,
Be thoroughly searched, swept, washed, and nearly sought,
To see if we can find the murther out:
And lest that Beech be thrown into the Thames,
Let charge be given unto the Watermen,
That if they see the body of a man,
Floating in any place about the Thames,
That straight they bring it unto Lambert hill,
Where Beech did dwell when he did live in health.

sp.speaker: 1. Neigh.
sp.l: I will see this charge performed immediately.
Now let us go to Master Beeches shop,
To see if that the boy can give us light,
Of those suspicions which this cause doth yield.
This is the house call master Loney forth,
Ho master Loney, doth the boy yet live,
Or can he utter who hath done him wrong.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: He is not dead but hath a dying life,
For neither speech, nor any sense at all,
Abideth in the poor unhappy youth.
Here you of any where his master is.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: No would we could, we all that knew his life,
Suspect him not for any such offence.

body.stage: Bringes him forth in a chaire, with a hammer sticking in his head.

sp.l: Bring forth the boy, that we may see his wounds.
What say the Surgeons to the young man's wounds,

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: They give him over, saying every wound
Of six, whereof there is seven in his head,
Are mortal wounds and all incurable.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How now good Harry, hast thou hid my fault?
The boy that knew I trained his master forth:
Lies speechless, and even at the point of death,
If you prove true, I hope to scape the brunt,

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.l: Why fear not me, I have concealed it yet,
And will conceal it, have no doubt of me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Thanks gentle Harry, thou shalt never lack,
But thou and I will live as faithful friends,
And what I have, shall be thine own to use:
There is some money for to spend today,
I know you mean to go and see the fair.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I fain would go, but that I want a cloak.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Thou shalt not want a cloak, or aught beside,
So thou wilt promise to be secret:
Here take my cloak, I will wear my best myself,
But where did you lie this last night?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: At the three Cranes, in a Carmans hay-loft,
But I will have better lodging soon at night,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Thou wilt be secret, I will go and see,
What stir they keep about Beeches shop,
Because I would avoid suspicion.
God save you gentlemen, is this the boy
That is reported to be murthered?
He is not dead outright, but pleased it God.
It were better he had left this wicked world,
Than to live thus in this extremity.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: A cruel hand no doubt that did the deed,
Why pull you not the hammer from his head.
That must not be before the youth be dead,
Because the crowner and his quest may see,
The manner how he did receive his death:
Bear hence the body, and endeavour all,
To find them out that did the villainy.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Do what you can, cast all your wits about,
Rake kennels, gutters, seek in every place,
Yet I will overgo your cunning heads,
If Williams and my sister hold their tongues:
My neighbours holds not me in least suspect,
Weighing of my former conversation:
Were Beeches boy well conveyed away,
I would hope to overblow this stormy day.

body.stage: Enter Falleria, Sostrata, Allenso, Pertillo: and two Murtherers booted.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Now little cousin, you are content to go
From me your uncle and your loving Aunt,
Your faithful cozen and your dearest friends:
And all to come to be a skilful man,
In learned arts and happy sciences.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I am content, because it pleaseth you,
My father bid I should obey your will,
And yield myself to your discretion;
Besides my cozen gave me yesternight,
A pretty Nag to ride to Padua,
Of all my friends Allenso loves me best.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I think thou art inspired with prophecy,
He loves thee better than I would he did:
Why wherefore think you so my pretty Nephew?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Because he taught me how to say my prayers,
To ride a horse, to start the fearful Hare,
He gave this dagger to me yester night,
This little Ring, and many pretty things:
For which, kind cousin, I rest your true debtor,
And one day I will make you recompense.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Aye, with thy lands and goods thou leavest behind.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: Pray father let me go along with him:
Now by the saviour of my sinful soul,
I do not like those fellows countenance.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Son be content, we will go a seven night hence,
And see him in his university weeds:
These will conduct him safely to the place,
Be well assured they will have a care of him,
That you shall never see Pertillo more.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Father, I pray you to withdraw yourself,
I would have a word or two in secrecy.

sp.speaker: Sost.
sp.l: Come living image of thy dead mother,
And take my loving farewell, ere we part,
I love thee dearly for thy fathers sake,
But for thy mothers, dote with jealousy,
O I do fear, before I see thy face,
Or thou, or I, shall taste of bitterness:
Kisse me sweet boy, and kissing fold thine Aunt,
Within the circle of thy little arms,
I need not fear, death cannot offer wrong,
The majesty of thy presaging face,
Would vanquish him though never so terrible,
The angry Lioness that is bereaved,
Of her imperious crew of forest kings,
Would leave her fury and defend thee safe,
From Wolves, from Panthers, Leopards, and she Bears,
That live by rapine, stealth, and cruelty,
Therefore to God I do commend thy state,
Who will be sure to guard thee tenderly.
And now to you, that carry hence this wealth,
This precious jewel, this unprized good,
have a regard to use him carefully,
When he is parted from that serious care,
Which was employed for his security:
I urge it not, that I misdoubt your truth,
I hope his Uncle doth persuade himself,
You will be courteous, kind and affable,
There is some reward for hoped carefulness.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Now by my soul I do suspect the men,
Especially the lower of the two:
See what a hollow discontented look
He casts, which brings apparent cause of fear,
The other, though he seem more courteous,
Yet doth his looks presage this thought in me,
As if he scorned to think on courtesy.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Upon my life, my son you are to blame,
The gentlemen are honest, virtuous,
And will protect Pertillo happily:
These thoughts proceed out of abundant love,
Because you grieve to leave his company:
If aught betide him otherwise than well,
Let God require due vengeance on my head,
And cut my hopes from all prosperity.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: A heavy sentence, full of wondrous fear,
I cannot choose but credit such a vow,
Come hither then, my joy, my chiefest hopes.
My second self, my earthly happiness,
Lend me thy little pretty cherry lip,
To kiss me cozen, lay thy little hand
Upon my cheek, and hug me tenderly,
Would the clear rays of thy two glorious suns,
Could penetrate the corners of my heart,
That thou might see, how much I tender thee.
My friends behold within this little bulk,
Two perfect bodies are incorporate,
His life holds mine, his heart contains my heart,
His every limb, contains my every part:
Without his being, I can never be,
He being dead, prepare to bury me.
O thou immortal mover of the spheres,
Within their circled revolutions,
Whose glorious image this small orphan bears,
Wrought by thy all sufficient Majesty,
O never suffer any wicked hand,
To harm this heavenly workmanship of thine,
But let him live, great God to honour thee,
With virtuous life, and spotless piety.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Cease my kind cousin, I cannot choose but weep,
To see your care of my security.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Knewest thou my reason, that persuades my heart,
Thou wouldst not wonder, why I grieve to part:
But yet I would suspect my fathers vow,
Did any other make it by your leave.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: What have you done, this loathness to depart,
Seems you were trained up in tediousness,
That know not when and where to make an end:
Take him my friends, I know you will discharge,
The hope and trust that I repose in you.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Assure yourself, in every circumstance.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Then to your horses, quickly, speedily,
Else we shall put our fingers in the eye,
And weep for kindness till tomorrow morn.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Farewell good Uncle, Aunt, and loving cousin.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Farewell, I fear me everlastingly.

body.stage: One of the murtherers takes Falleria by the sleeue.

sp.speaker: 1. mu.
sp.l: You mean not now to have him murthered?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Not murthered, what else? kill him I say,
But wherefore makest thou question of my will?

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.l: Because you wished that God should be revenged
If any ill be tide the innocent.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: O that was nothing but to blind the eyes,
Of my fond son, which loves him too too well.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.l: It is enough, it shall be surely done.

body.stage: Enter Merry and Rachel with a bag.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What hast thou sped? have you bought the bag?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Aye brother, here it is, what is it to do?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: To bear hence Beeches body in the night.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: You cannot bear so great a weight yourself,
And it is no trusting of another man.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes well enough, as I will order it,
I will cut him piecemeal, first his head and legs
Will be one burthen, then the mangled rest,
Will be another, which I will transport,
Beyond the water in a Ferry boat,
And throw it into Paris-garden ditch.
Fetch me the chopping-knife, and in the mean
I will move the Faggots that do cover him.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: O can you find in heart to cut and carve,
His stone cold flesh, and rob the greedy grave,
Of his dissevered blood be sprinkled limbs?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Aye marry can I fetch the chopping knife.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: This deed is worse, than when you took his life.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But worse, or better, now it must be so,
Better do thus, than feel a greater woe.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Here is the knife, I cannot stay to see,
This barbarous deed of inhumanity.

body.stage: Merry begins to cut the body, and bindes the armes behinde his backe with Beeches garters, leaues out the body, couers the head and legs againe.

sp.speaker: Truth
sp.l: Ye glorious beams of that bright-shining lamp,
That lights the star bespangled firmament,
And dimness the glimmering shadows of the night,
Why dost thou lend assistance to this wretch,
To shamble forth with bold audacity,
His limbs, that bears thy makers semblance.
All you the sad spectators of this Act,
Whose hearts do taste a feeling pensiveness,
Of this unheard of savage Massacre:
O be far off, to harbour such a thought,
As this audacious murtherer put in ure,
I see your sorrows flow up to the brim,
And overflow your cheeks with brinish tears,
But though this sight bring surfeit to the eye,
Delight your ears with pleasing harmony,
That ears may countercheck your eyes, and say,
Why shed you tears, this deed is but a play:
His work is done, he seeks to hide his sin,
I will wail his woe, before his woe begin.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Now will I high me to the water side,
And fling this heavy burthen in a ditch,
Whereof my soul doth feel so great a weight,
That it doth almost press me down with fear,
Hark Rachel: I will cross the water straight,
And fling this middle mention of a man,
Into some ditch, then high me home again,
To rid my house of that is left behind.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Where have you laid the legs and battered head?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Under the faggots, where it lay before,
Help me to put this trunk into the bag.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: My heart will not endure to handle it,
The sight here of doth make me quake for fear.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I will do it myself, only, dry up the blood,
And burn the clothes as you have done before.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: I fear thy soul will burn in flames of hell,
Unless repentance wash away thy sin,
With cleansing tears of true contrition:
Ah did not nature oversway my will,
The world should know this plot of damned ill.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I am so weary in this cumbrous wood,
That I must needs go sit me down and rest.

sp.speaker: 1. Mur.
sp.l: What were we best to kill him unawares,
Or give him notice what we do intend?

sp.speaker: 2. Mur.
sp.l: Why then belike you mean to do your charge
And feel no taste of pity in your heart.

sp.speaker: 1. Mur.
sp.l: Of pity man, that never enters here,
And if it should, I would threat my craven heart,
To stab it home, for harbouring such a thought,
I see no reason why I should relent:
It is a charitable virtuous deed,
To end this princox from this sinful world.

sp.speaker: 2. Mur.
sp.l: Such charity will never have reward,
Unless it be with sting of conscience:
And that is a torment worse than Sisipus,
That rolls a restless stone against the hill.

sp.speaker: 1. Mur.
sp.l: My conscience is not pricked with such conceit.

sp.speaker: 2. Mur.
sp.l: That shows thee further off from hoped grace.

sp.speaker: 1. Mur.
sp.l: Grace me no graces, I respect no grace,
But with a grace, to give a graceless stab,
To chop folks legs and arms off by the stumps,
To see what shift they will make to scramble home:
Pick out men's eyes, and tell them that is the sport,
Of hood-man-blind, without all sportiveness,
If with a grace I can perform such pranks,
My heart will give mine agents many thanks.

sp.speaker: 2. Mur.
sp.l: Then God forbid I should consort myself,
With one so far from grace and piety:
Lest being found within thy company,
I should be partner of thy punishment.

sp.speaker: 1. Mur.
sp.l: When we have done what we have vowed to do,
My heart desires to have no fellowship,
With those that talk of grace of godliness:
I named not God unless it were with an oath,
Sense the first hour that I could walk alone,
(And you that make so much of conscience,
By heaven thou art a damned hypocrite:
For thou hast vowed to kill that sleeping boy,
And all to gain two hundredth marks in gold,
I know this pureness comes of pure deceit,
To draw me from the murthering of the child,
That you alone might have the benefit,
You are too shallow, if you gull me so,
Chop off my head to make a Sousing-tub,
And fill it full of tripes and chitterlings.

sp.speaker: 2. Mur.
sp.l: That thou shalt see my heart is far from fraud,
Or vain illusion in this enterprise,
Which doth import the safety of our souls,
There take my earnest of impiety.
Only forbear to lay thy iuder hands,
Upon the poor mistrust-less tender child,
As for our vows, fear not their violence,
God will forgive on hearty penitence.

sp.speaker: 1. Mur.
sp.l: Thou Eunuch, Capon, dastard, fast and loose,
Thou weathercock of mutability,
White livered Peasant, wilt thou vow and swear,
Face and make semblance with thy bagpipe oaths,
Of that thou never meanest to execute?
Pure cowardice for fear to crack thy neck,
With the huge Caos of thy bodies weight,
Hath sure begot this true contrition,
Then fast and pray, and see if thou canst win,
A goodly pardon for thy heinous sin,
As for the boy, this fatal instrument,
Was marked by heaven to cut his line of life,
And must supply the knife of Atropos,
And if it do not, let this master piece,
(Which nature lent the world to wonder at)
Be slit in Carbonadoes for the jaws,
Of some men-eating hungry Cannibal:
By heaven I will kill him only for this cause,
For that he came of virtuous Ancestors,

sp.speaker: 2. m.
sp.l: But by that God, which made that wondrous globe,
Wherein is seen his powerful deity,
Thou shalt not kill him maugre all thy spite:
Swear, and forswear thyself ten thousand times,
Awake Pertillo, for thou art betrayed,
This bloody slave intends to murther thee.

sp.speaker: 1. Mur.
sp.l: Both him, and all, that dare to rescue him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Wherefore? because I slept without your leave?
Forgive my fault, I will never sleep again.

sp.speaker: 2. mur.
sp.l: No child, thy wicked Uncle hath suborned,
Both him and me to take thy life away:
Which I would save, but that this hellish imp,
Will not consent to spare thy guiltless blood.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why should Falleria seek to have my life.

sp.speaker: 2. mur.
sp.l: The lands and goods, thy father left his son,
Do hale thee on to thy destruction.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: O needy treasure, harm be getting good,
That safely should procure the loss of blood.

sp.speaker: 2. mu.
sp.l: Those lands and goods, thy father got with pain,
Are swords where with his little son is slain.

sp.speaker: 1. mu.
sp.l: Then let our swords let out his gutless life.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sweet, sour, kind, cruel, hold thy murthering knife,
And here me speak, before you murther me.

sp.speaker: 2. mu.
sp.l: Fear not sweet child, he shall not murther thee.

sp.speaker: 1. mu.
sp.l: No, but my sword shall let his puddings forth.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: First hear me speak, thou map of Butchery,
It is but my goods and lands my Uncle seeks,
Having that safely, he desires no more,
I do protest by my dead parents souls,
By the dear love of false Fallerios son,
Whose heart, my heart assures me, will be grieved,
To hear his fathers inhumanity:
I will forsake my country, goods, and lands,
I and myself, will even change myself,
In name, in life, in habit, and in all,
And live in some far moved continent,
So you will spare my weak and tender youth,
Which cannot entertain the stroke of death,
In budding years, and very spring of life.

sp.speaker: 1. Mur.
sp.l: Leave of these bootless protestations,
And use no ruth enticing arguments,
For if you do, I will lop you limb by limb,
And torture you for childish eloquence.

sp.speaker: 2. Mur.
sp.l: Thou shalt not make his little finger ache.

sp.speaker: 1. Mur.
sp.l: Yes every part, and this shall prove it true.

body.stage: Runnes Pertillo in with his sworde.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: O I am slain, the Lord forgive thy fact,
And give thee grace to die with penitence.

sp.speaker: 2. Mur.
sp.l: A treacherous villain, full of cowardice,
I will make thee know that thou hast done amiss.

sp.speaker: 1. m.
sp.l: Teach me that knowledge when you will or dare.

body.stage: They fight and kill one another, the relenter hauing some more life, and the other dyeth.

sp.speaker: 1. mur.
sp.l: 'Swounds I am peppered, I had need have salt,
Or else tomorrow I shall yield a stink,
Worse than a heap of dirty excrements:
Now by this Hilt, this gold was earned too dear:
Ah, how now death, wilt thou be conqueror?
Then vengeance light on them that made me so,
And there is another farewell ere I go.

sp.speaker: 2. mur.
sp.l: Enough, enough, I had my death before.

body.stage: Enter the Duke of Padua, Turqualo, Vesuvio, Alberto, etc.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How now my Lords, was it not a gallant course,
Believe me sirs, I never saw a wretch,
Make better shift to save her little life:
The thickets full of busks and scratching briars,
A mighty dew, a many deep mouthed hounds,
Let loose in every place to cross their course,
And yet the Hare got cleanly from them all:
I would not for a hundred pound in faith,
But that she had escaped with her life,
For we will wind a merry hunters horn,
And start her once again tomorrow morn.

sp.speaker: Tarq.
sp.l: In troth my Lord, the little flocked hound,
That had but three good legs to further him,
It was foremost still, and surer of his sent,
Than anyone in all the cry besides.

sp.speaker: Vesu.
sp.l: But yet Pendragon gave the Hare more turns.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: That was because he was more politic,
And eyed her closely in her coverts still:
They all did well, and once more we will try,
The subtle creature with a greater cry,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But say, what well accomplished Gentleman,
Is this that comes into our company?

sp.speaker: Vesu.
sp.l: I know him well, it is Fallerios son,
Pandynos brother (a kind Gentleman)
That died, and left his little pretty son,
Unto his fathers good direction.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Stand close awhile, and over hear his words,
He seems much over-gone with passion.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: Ye timorous thoughts that guide my giddy steps,
In unknown paths of dreadful wilderness,
Why traitor-like do you conspire to hold,
My pained heart, betwixt fear and jealousy,
My too much care hath brought me carelessly,
Into this woody savage labyrinth,
And I can find no way to issue out,
Fear hath so dazzled all my better part,
That reason hath forgot discretions art:
But in good time, see where is company.
Kind Gentlemen, if you unlike myself,
Are not encumbered with the circling ways,
Of this erroneous winding wilderness,
I pray you to direct me forth this wood,
And show the path that leads to Padua.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We all are Paduans, and we all intend,
To pass forth with, with speed to Padua.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: I will attend upon you presently.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come then away, but gentlemen behold,
bloody sight, and murtherous spectacle.

sp.speaker: 2. Mur.
sp.l: O God forgive me all my wickedness,
And take me to eternal happiness.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hark one of them hath some small spark of life,
To kindle knowledge of their sad mishaps.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: Ah gracious Lord, I know this wretched child,
And these two men that here lie murthered.

sp.speaker: Vesu.
sp.l: Do you Alenso?

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Aye my gracious Lord.
It was Pertillo my dead Uncles son:
Now have my fears brought forth this fearful child,
Of endless care, and everlasting grief.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Lay hands upon Alenso Gentlemen,
Your presence doth confirm you had a share,
In the performance of this cruelty.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: I do confess I have so great a share,
In this mishap, that I will give him thanks,
That will let forth my sorrow wounded soul,
From out this goal of lamentation.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It is now too late to wish for hadiwist,
Had you withheld your hand from this attempt,
Sorrow had never so imprisoned you.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: O my good Lord, you do mistake my case,
And yet my grief is sure infallible,
The Lord of heaven can witness with my soul,
That I am guiltless of your wrong suspect,
But yet not griefless that the deed is done.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Nay if you stand to justify yourself,
This Gentleman whose life doth seem to stay,
Within his body tell he tell your shame,
Shall testify of your integrity:
peak then thou sad Anatomy of death,
Who were the agents of your woefulness.

sp.speaker: 2. Mur.
sp.l: O be not blinded with a false surmise,
For lest my tongue should fail to end the tale.
Of our untimely fate appointed death:
Know young Allenso is as innocent,
As is Fallerio guilty of the crime.
He, he it was, that with four hundredth marks,
Whereof two hundred he paid presently,
Did hire this damned villain and myself,
To massacre this harmless innocent:
But yet my conscience touched with some remorse,
Would fain have saved the young Pertillos life,
But he remorseless would not let him live,
But unawares thrust in his harmless breast,
That life bereaving fatal instrument:
Which cruel deed I seeking to revenge,
Have lost my life, and paid the slave his due
Reward, for spilling blood of Innocents:
Surprise Fallerio author of this ill,
Save young Allenso, he is guiltless still.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: O sweetest honey mixed with bitter gall,
O Nightingale combined with Ravens notes,
Thy speech is like a woodward that should say,
Let the tree live, but take the root away.
As though my life were aught but misery,
Having my father slain for infamy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What should incite Fallerio to devise,
The overthrow of this unhappy boy.

sp.speaker: Vesu.
sp.l: That may be easily guest my gracious Lord,
To be the lands Pandino left his son,
Which after that the boy were murthered,
Descend to him by due inheritance.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You deem aright, see gentlemen the fruits
Of coveting to have another's right,
O wicked thought of greedy covetise,
Could neither nature, fear of punishment,
Scandal to wife and children, nor the fear,
Of Gods confounding strict severity,
Allay the head-strong fury of thy will,
Beware my friends to wish unlawful gain.
It will beget strange actions full of fear,
And overthrow the actor unawares,
For first Fallerios life must satisfy,
The large effusion of their guiltless bloods,
Trained on by him to these extremities,
Next, wife and children must be dispossessed,
Of lands and goods, and turned to beggary,
But most of all, his great and heinous sin,
Will be an eye sore to his guiltless kin.
Bear hence away these models of his shame,
And let us prosecute the murtherer,
With all the care and diligence we can.

body.stage: Two must be carrying away Pertillo.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Forbear a while, to bear away my joy,
Which now is vanished, since his life is fled,
And give me leave to wash his deadly wound,
With hearty tears, out-flowing from those eyes,
Which loved his sight, more than the sight of heaven:
Forgive me God for this idolatry.
Thou ugly monster, grim imperious death,
Thou raw-bond lump of foul deformity.
Regardless instrument of cruel fate,
Unpartial Sergeant, full of treachery,
Why didst thou flatter my ill boding thoughts,
And flesh my hopes with vain illusions:
Why didst thou say, Pertillo should not die,
And yet, O yet, hast done it cruelly:
O but behold, with what a smiling cheer,
He entertained thy bloody harbinger:
See thou transformer of a heavenly face,
To Ashy paleness and unpleasing looks,
That his fair countenance still retaineth grace,
Of perfect beauty in the very grave,
The world would say such beauty should not die,
Yet like a thief thou didst it cruelly:
Ah, had thy eyes deep sunk into thy head,
Been able to perceive his virtuous mind,
Where virtue sate enthroned in a chair,
With awful grace, and pleasing majesty:
Thou wouldst not then have let Pertillo die,
Nor like a thief have slain him cruelly.
Inevitable fates, could you devise,
No means to bring me to this pilgrimage,
Full of great woes and sad calamities,
But that the father should be principal,
To plot the present downfall of the son:
Come then kind death and give me leave to die,
Since thou hast slain Pertillo cruelly.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Forbear Allenso hearken to my doom,
Which doth concern thy fathers apprehension,
First we enjoin thee upon pain of death,
To give no succour to thy wicked sire,
But let him perish in his damned sin,
And pay the price of such a treachery:
See that with speed the monster be attached,
And bring him safe to suffer punishment,
Prevent it not, nor seek not to delude,
The officers to whom this charge is given,
For if thou do, as sure as God doth live:
Thyself shall satisfy the laws contempt,
Therefore forward about this punishment.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Thanks gracious God that thou hast left the means
To end my soul from this perplexity,
Not succour him on pain of present death:
That is no pain, death is a welcome guest,
To those whose hearts are overwhelmed with grief,
My woes are done, I having leave to die,
And after death live ever joyfully.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.l: Now Auarice I have well satisfied,
My hungry thoughts with blood and cruelty:
Now all my melancholy discontent,
Is shaken off, and I am thoroughly pleased,
With what thy policy hath brought to pass,
Yet am I not so thoroughly satisfied:
Until I bring the purple actors forth,
And cause them quaff a bowl of bitterness,
That father, son, and sister brother may,
Bring to their deaths with most assured decay.

sp.speaker: Aua.
sp.l: That will be done without all question,
For thou hast slain Allenso with the boy:
And Rachell doth not wish to over-live,
The sad remembrance of her brothers sin,
Leave faithful love, to teach them how to die,
That they may snare their kinsfolks misery.

body.stage: Enter Merry and Rachell vncouering the head and legges.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I have bestowed a watery funeral,
On the half body of my butchered friend,
The head and legs I will leave in some dark place,
I care not if they find them yea or no.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Where do you mean to leave the head and legs,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: In some dark place near to Bainardes castle,

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: But do it closely that you be not seen,
For all this while you are without suspect.

body.stage: Puts on his cloake taketh vp the bag.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Take you no thought, I will have a care of that,
Only take heed you have a special care,
To make no show of any discontent,
Nor use too many words to anyone.
I will return when I have left my load,
Be merry Rachell half the fear is past.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: But I shall never think myself secure,
This deed would trouble any quiet soul,
To think thereof, much more to see it done,
Such cruel deeds can never long be hid,
Although we practice never so cunningly,
Let others open what I do conceal,
Lo he is my brother, I will cover it,
And rather die than have it spoken rife,
Lo where she goes, betrayed her brothers life.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Why how now Harry what should be the cause,
That you are grown so discontent of late:
Your sighs do show some inward heaviness,
Your heavy looks, your eyes brimful of tears,
Bears testimony of some secret grief,
Reveal it Harry, I will be thy friend,
And help thee to my poor hability.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: If I am heavy, if I often sigh,
Condemn me not, for I have mighty cause,
More than I will impart to anyone.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Do you misdoubt me, that you dare not tell
That woe to me, that moves your discontent.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Good master Cowley you were ever kind,
But pardon me, I will not utter it,
To anyone, for I have past my word,
And therefore urge me not to tell my grief.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: But those that smother grief too secretly,
May waste themselves in silent anguish,
And bring their bodies to so low an ebb,
That all the world can never make is flow,
Unto the happy hight of former health:
Then be not injurious to thyself,
To waste thy strength in lamentation,
But tell thy case, we will seek some remedy.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: My cause of grief is now remediless,
And all the world can never lessen it,
Then since no means can make my sorrows less,
Suffer me wail a woe which wants redress.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Yet let me bear a part in thy laments,
I love thee not so ill, but I will moan,
Thy heavy haps, thou shalt not sigh alone.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Nay, if you are so curious to intrude,
Yourself to sorrow, where you have no share,
I will frequent some unfrequented place,
Where none shall hear nor see my lamentations.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: And I will follow where soever thou go,
I will be partner of thy helpless woe.
Will is it not time we should go to our boats,
And give attendance for this Bartlemew tide:
Folks will be stirring early in the morning.
By my troth I am indifferent whether I go or no.
sp.p:
If a fare come why so, if not, why so, if I have not their
money, they shall have none of my labour.

sp.l: But we that live by our labours, must give attendance,
But where lies thy Boat?
At Baynards castle stairs.
So does mine, then let us go together.
Come, I am indifferent, I care not so much for going,
But if I go with you, why so: if not, why so.
'sblood what rascal hath laid this in my way?

body.stage: Taking the Sack by the end, one of the legs and head drops out.

sp.p:
He was not very indifferent that did so, but you are so
perementory, to say, why so, and why so, that everyone is
glad to do you injury, but let us see, what is it?
sp.stage: Taking the Sack by the end, one of the legs and head drops out.
sp.p: Good Lord deliver us, a man's legs, and a head with many wounds.

What is that so much, I am indifferent, yet for mine
own part, I understand the misery of it, if you do, why
so, if not, why so.

sp.l: By my troth I understand no other mystery but this,
It is a strange and very rueful sight,
But prithee what dost thou conceit of it.

sp.p:
In troth I am indifferent for if I tell you, why so, it not
why so.

If thou tell me, I will thank thee, therefore I prithee
tell me.

sp.l: I tell you I am indifferent, but to be plain with you,
I am grieved to stumble at the hangman's budget.
At the hangman's budget, why this is a sack.

sp.p:
And to speak indifferently, it is the hang-mans
Budget, and because he thought too much of his labour to
set this head upon the bridge, and the legs upon the gates,
he flings them in the street for men to stumble at, but if I
get him in my boat, I will so belabour him in a stretcher,
that he had better be stretched in one of his own half penny
halters: if this be a good conceit, why so, if not, why so.

sp.l: Thou art deceived, this head hath many wounds,
And hose and shoes remaining on the legs,
Bull always strips all quartered traitors quite.

sp.p:
I am indifferent whether you believe me or no,
these were not worth taking off, and therefore he left them
on, if this be likely why so, if not, why so.

sp.l: Nay then I see you grow from worse to worse,
I heard last night, that one near Lambert hill
Was missing, and his boy was murthered,
It may be this is a part of that same man:
What ever it be, I will bear it to that place.
Mass I am indifferent, I will go along with you,
If it be so, why so, if not why so.

body.stage: Enter three neighbors knocking at Loneys doore: Loney comes.

sp.l: Ho master Loney, hear you any news,
What is become of your Tenant Beech?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: No truly sir, not any news at all.
What hath the boy recovered any speech,
To give us light of these suggestions,
That do arise upon this accident.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: There is no hope he should recover speech,
The wives do say, he is ready now to leave
This grievous world full fraught with treachery,
Methinks if Beech himself be innocent,
That then the murtherer should not dwell far off,
The hammer that is sticking in his head,
Was borrowed of a Cutler dwelling by,
But he remembers not, who borrowed it:
He is committed that did owe the hammer,
But yet he stands upon his innocence,
And Beeches absence causeth great suspicion.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: If Beech be faulty, as I do not think,
I never was so much deceived before,
O had you known his conversation,
