You would not have him in suspicion.
Devils seem Saints, and in this hateful times,
Deceit can bear apparent signs of trueth,
And vice bear show of virtues excellence.
I pray is this master Beeches house?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: My friend this same was master Beeches shop,
We cannot tell whether he live or no.
Know you his head and if I show it you,
Or can you tell what hose or shoes he ware,
At that same time when he forsook the shop.
What have you head, and hose, and shoes to show,
And want the body that should use the same.
Behold this head, these legs, these hose and shoes,
And see if they were Beeches yea or no.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: They are the same, alas what is become,
Of the remainder of this wretched man.

sp.speaker: 1. VVat.
sp.l: Nay that I know not, only these we found,
As we were coming up a narrow lane,
Near Baynardes Castle, where we two did dwell,
And hearing that a man was missing hence,
We thought it good to bring these to this place,

sp.p: Thanks my good friends, there is something for your pains,

sp.speaker: 2. Wat.
sp.p:
We are indifferent, whether you give us anything
or nothing, and if you had not, why so, but since you have,
why so.

sp.speaker: 1. VVat.
sp.l: Leave your repining sir we thank you heartily.

body.stage: Enter a Porter and a gentleman.

sp.l: Farewell good fellows, neighbour now be bold,
They dwell not far that did this bloody deed,
As God no doubt will at the last reveal:
Though they conceal it never so cunningly,
All houses, gutters, since and crevices,
have carefully been sought for, for the blood.
Yet there is no instance found in any place.
But who is that, that brings a heavy load,
Behind him on a painful porters back.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Pray gentlemen which call you Beeches shop?

sp.speaker: 3. Neig.
sp.l: This is the place, what would you with the man?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Nothing with him, I hear the man is dead,
And if he be not, I have lost my pains.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: He is dead indeed, but yet we cannot find,
What is become of half his hopeless body,
His head and legs are found but for the rest,
No man can tell what is become of it.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Then I do think I can resolve your doubt,
And bring you certain tidings of the rest,
And if you know his doublet and his shirt:
As for the body it is so abused.
That no man can take notice whose it was,
Set down this burthen of another's shame,
What do you know the doublet and the shirt.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: This is the doublet, these the severed limbs,
Which late were joined to that mangled trunk:
Lay them together see if they can make,
Among them all a sound and solid man.

sp.speaker: 3. neigh.
sp.l: They all agree, but yet they cannot make,
That sound and whole, which a remorseless hand
Hath severed with a knife of cruelty:
But say good sir, where did you find this out?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Walking betime by Paris-garden ditch,
Having my Water Spaniel by my side,
When we approached unto that hapless place,
Where this same trunk lay drowned in a ditch,
My Spaniel gan to sent, to bark, to plunge,
Into the water and came forth again,
And fawned on me, as if a man should say,
Help out a man that here lies murthered.
At first I took delight to see the dog,
Thinking in vain some game did there lie hid,
Amongst the Nettles growing near the bank:
But when no game, nor anything appeared,
That might produce the Spaniel to this sport,
I gan to rate and beat the harmless Cur,
Thinking to make him leave to follow me,
But words, nor blows, could move the dog away,
But still he plunged, he dived, he barked, he ran
Still to my side, as if it were for help:
I seeing this, did make the ditch be dragged,
Where then was found this body as you see,
With great amazement to the lookers on.
Behold the mighty miracles of God,
That senseless things should propagate their sin,
That are more bestial far than beastliness,
Of any creature most insensible.

sp.speaker: 2 neigh.
sp.l: Cease we to wonder at Gods wondrous works,
And let us labour for to bring to light,
Those masked fiends that thus dishonour him:
This sack is new, and lo behold his mark
Remains upon it, which did sell the bag,
Amongst the Salters we shall find it out,
When, and to whom, this bloody bag was sold.
It is very likely, let no pains be spared,
To bring it out, if it be possible,
It were pity such a murther should remain
Unpunished, amongst Turks and Infidels.

sp.speaker: 1. neigh.
sp.l: Sirs, I do know the man that sold this bag,
And if you please, I will fetch him presently?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: With all our hearts, how say you Gentlemen?
Perchance the murther thus may come to light.
I pray you do it, we will tarry here:
And let the eyes of every passenger
Be satisfied, which may example be,
How they commit so dreadful wickedness.

sp.speaker: wom.
sp.l: And please your masterships the boy is dead.

sp.speaker: 3. neigh.
sp.l: It is very strange, that having many wounds,
So terrible, so ghastly, which is more,
Having the hammer sticking in his head,
That he should live and stir from Friday night,
To Sunday morning, and even then depart,
When that his Masters mangled course were found,
Bring him forth too, perchance the murtherers
May have their hearts touched with due remorse,
Viewing their deeds of damned wickedness.

body.stage: Bring forth the boye and lay him by Beech.

sp.speaker: 1. neigh.
sp.l: Here is the Salters man that sold the bag,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My friend, how long since did you sell that bag?
And unto whom, if you remember it?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: I sold the bag good sir but yesterday,
Unto a maid, I do not know her name.

sp.speaker: 3. neigh.
sp.l: Nor where she dwells.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: No certainly.

sp.speaker: 2. neigh.
sp.l: But what apparel had she on her back?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: I do not well remember what she wore,
But if I saw her I should know her sure.

body.stage: Go to one house, and knock at doore, asking,

sp.speaker: 3. neigh.
sp.l: Go round about to every neighbour's house,
And will them show their maids immediately:
God grant we may find out the murtherers.
Bring forth such maids as are within your house.

sp.speaker: 1. housekeeper.
sp.l: I have but one, I will send her down to you.

sp.speaker: 3. neigh.
sp.l: Is this the maid.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.l: No sir, this is not she.
How many maids do dwell within this house?

sp.speaker: 2. house.
sp.l: Here is never a woman here, except my wife.

sp.speaker: 3. neigh.
sp.l: Whose house is this?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: An honest civil man's, called Master Merry,
Who I dare be sworn, would never do so great a murther
But you may ask here too for fashion sake.
How now fair maid, dwells any here but you?
Thou hast too true a face for such a deed.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: No gentle sir, my brother keeps no more.

sp.speaker: 3. neigh.
sp.l: This is not she?

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.l: No truly gentleman.
This will not serve, we cannot find her out,
Bring in those bodies, it grows towards night,
God bring these damned murtherers at length to light.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why go the neighbours round about the street
To every house? what hast thou heard the cause?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: They go about with that same Salters man,
Of whom I bought the bag but yesterday,
To see if he can know the maid again
Which bought it, this I think the very cause.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How were my senses overcome with fear,
That I could not foresee this jeopardy:
For had I brought the bag away with me,
They had not had this means to find it out.
Hide thee above lest that the Salters man,
Take notice of thee that thou art the maid,
And by that knowledge we be all undone.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: That fear is past, I saw, I spake with him,
Yet he denies that I did buy the bag:
Besides, the neighbours have no doubt of you,
Saying you are an honest harmless man,
And made enquiry here for fashion sake.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My former life, deserves their good conceits,
Were it not blemished with this treachery.
My heart is merrier than it was before,
For now I hope the greatest fear is past,
The hammer is denied, the bag unknown,
Now there is left no means to bring it out,
Unless ourselves prove Traitors to ourselves.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: When saw you Harry Williams?

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: Why today
I met him coming home from Powles Cross,
Where he had been to hear a Sermon.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Why brought you not the man along with you
To come to dinner, that we might persuade
Him to continue in his secrecy.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I did entreat him, but he would not come,
But vowed to be as secret as myself.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: What, did he swear?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What need you ask me that?
You know we never heard him swear an oath.
But since he hath concealed the thing thus long,
I hope in God he will conceal it still.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Pray God he do, and then I have no doubt,
But God will overpass this grievous sin,
If you lament with true unfeigned tears,
And seek to live the remnant of your years,
In Gods true fear with upright conscience.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: If it would please him pardon this amiss,
And rid my body from the open shame,
That doth attend this deed, being brought to light,
I would endeavour all my coming days,
To please my maker, and exalt his praise:
But it grows late, come bring me to my bed,
That I may rest my sorrow charged head.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Rest still in calm secure tranquillity,
And over-blow this storm of mighty fear,
With pleasant gales of hoped quietness,
Go when you will, I will attend, and pray,
To send this woeful night a cheerful day.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Pass over these rugged sorrow's of laments,
And come to plainer paths of cheerfulness,
Cease thy continual showers of thy woe,
And let my pleasing words of comfort chase,
This dusky clouds of thy unjust despair,
Far from thy heart, and let a pleasing hope,
Of young Pertillos happy safe return,
Establish all your ill divining thoughts,
So shall you make me cheerful that am sad,
And feed your hopes with fond illusions.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: I could be so, but my divided soul,
Betwixt fear and hope of young Pertillos life,
Cannot arrive at the desired port,
Of firm belief, until mine eyes do see,
Him that I sent to know the certainty.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: To know the certainty, of whom, of what,
Whom, whether when, or wherewith I pray,
have you dispatched a frustrate messenger,
By heaven, and earth, my heart misgiveth me,
They will prevent my cunning policy.
Why speak you not what winged Pegasus,
Is posted for your satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: Methinks my speech reveals a hidden fear,
And that fear tells me, that the child is dead.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: By sweet S. Andrew and my fathers soul,
I think the peevish boy be too too well:
But speak, who was your passions harbinger.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: One that did kindle my misdoubting thoughts,
With the large flame of his timidity.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: O then I know the tinder of your fear,
Was young Allenso your white honey son:
Confusion light upon his timorous head,
For broaching this large stream of fearfulness,
And all the plagues that damned furies feel,
For their forepassed bold iniquities:
Afflict you both for thus preventing me.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: Preventing you, of what, Fallerio speak,
For if you do not, my poor heart will break.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Why of the good that I had purposed,
To young Pertillo, which I would conceal,
From you, and him, until the deed were done.

sp.speaker: Sost.
sp.l: If it were good, then we affect him dear,
And would add furtherance to your enterprise.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I say your close ease-dropping policies,
have hindered him of greater benefits,
Than I can ever do him after this:
If he live long, and grow to riper sin,
He will curse you both, that thus have hindered
His freedom from this goal of sinful flesh:
But let that pass, when went your harebrained son,
That Cuckoo virtue-singing, hateful bird,
To guard the safety of his better part,
Which he hath penned within the childish coop,
Of young Pertillos sweet security.

sp.speaker: Sost.
sp.l: That lovely son, that comfort of my life,
That root of virtuous magnanimity,
That doth affect with an unfeigned love,
That tender boy, which under heavens bright eye,
Deserveth most to be affected dear,
Went some two hours after the little boy
Was sent away, to keep at Padua.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: What is he lovely? he is a loathsome toad,
A one eyed Cyclops, a stigmatic brat,
That durst attempt to contradict my will,
And pry into my close intendments.
Mass here he comes, his downcast sullen look,
Is over weighed with mighty discontent,
I hope the brat is posted to his sire,
That he is grown so lazy of his pace:
Forgetful of his duty, and his tongue,
Is even fast tied with strings of heaviness.
Come hither boy, sawest thou my obstacle,
That little Dromus that crept into my son,
With friendly hand, removed and thrust away,
Say I, and please me with the sweetest note,
That ever relished in a mortals mouth.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: I am a Swan that singe before I die,
Your note of shame and coming misery.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Speak softly son, let not thy mother hear,
She was almost dead before for very fear.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: Would I could roar as instruments of war,
Wall battering Cannons, when the Gun-powder
Is touched with part of Etnas Element,
Would I could bellow like enraged Bulls,
Whose hearts are full of indignation,
To be captived by human policy:
Would I could thunder like Almighty Ioue,
That sends his far heard voice too terrific,
The wicked hearts of earthly citizens:
Then roaring, bellowing, thundering, I would say,
Mother lament, Pertillos made away.

sp.speaker: Sost.
sp.l: What is he dead, God give me leave to die,
And him repentance for his treachery.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Never the like impiety was done,
A mother slain, with terror of the son:
Help to repair the damage thou hast made,
And seek to call back life with diligence.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Call back a happy creature to more woe,
That were a sin, good Father let her go:
O happy I, if my tormenting smart,
Could rend like here is, my grief afflicted heart,
Would your hard heart extend unto your wife,
To make her live and everdying life.
What is she dead? O then thrice happy she,
Whose eyes are bard from our calamity.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Aye all too soon, thou viper, parricide,
But for thy tongue thy mother had not died,
That belching voice, that harsh night-raven sound,
Untimely sent thy mother to the ground,
Upbraid my fault, I did deceive my brother,
Cut out thy tongue, that slew thy careful mother.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: God love my soul, as I in heart rejoice,
To have such power in my death bringing voice,
See how in stead of tears and hearty sighs:
Of folded arms and sorrow speaking looks,
I do behold with cheerful countenance,
The lifeless root of my nativity:
And thank her hasty soul that thence did go,
To keep her from her son and husbands woe.
Now father give attention to my tale:
I will not dip my grief deciphering tongue,
In bitter words of reprehension,
Your deeds have thrown more mischiefs on your head
Than wit or reason can remove again:
For to be brief, Pertillo, O that name
Cannot be named without a hearty sigh,
Is murthered, and,

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What and, this news is good.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: The men which you suborned to murther him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Better and better, then it cannot out,
Unless your love will be so scrupulous,
That it will overthrow yourself and me.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: The best is last, and yet you hinder me,
The Duke of Padua hunting in the wood:
Accompanied with Lords and gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: 'Swounds what of that? what good can come of that?

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Was made acquainted by the one of them,
(That had some little remnant of his life:)
With all your practice and conspiracy?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I would that remnant had fled quick to hell,
To fetch fierce finds to rend their carcasses,
Rather than bring my life in jeopardy:
Is this the best, 'Swounds do you mock me son,
And make a jest at my calamity.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Not I good father, I will ease your woe,
If you but yield unto my policy.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Declare it then, my wits are now to seek,
That piece of life hath so confounded me,
That I am wholly overcome with fear.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: The duke hath vowed to prosecute your life,
With all the strict severity he can,
But I will cross his resolution:
And keep you from his fury well enough,
I will wear your habit, I will seem the man,
That did suborn the bloody murtherers,
I will not stir from out this house of woe,
But weight the coming of the officers,
And answer for you fore the angry Duke,
And if need be suffer your punishment.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I will none of that, I do not like the last,
I love thee dearer than I do my life,
And all I did, was to advance thy state,
To sun bright beams of shining happiness.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Doubt not my life, for when I do appear
Before the duke, I being not the man,
He can inflict no punishment on me.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Mass thou sayst true, he cannot punish thee,
Thou wert no actor of their Tragedy:
But for my beard thou canst not counterfeit,
And bring gray hairs upon thy downy chin,
White frosts are never seen in summers spring.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: I bought a beard this day at Padua,
Such as our common actors use to wear:
When youth would put on ages countenance,
So like in shape, in colour, and in all,
To that which grows upon your aged face,
That were I dressed in your habiliments,
Yourself would scarcely know me from yourself.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: That is excellent, what shape hast thou devised,
To be my vizard to delude the world.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Why thus, I will presently shave off your hair,
And dress you in a lowly shepherds weed,
Then you will seem to have the careful charge,
Of some wealth bringing rich and fleecy flock,
And so pass currant from suspicion.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: This care of thine my son doth testify,
Nature in thee hath firm predominance,
That neither loss of friend, nor vile reproach,
Can shake thee with their strongest violence:
In this disguise, I will see the end of thee,
That thou acquitted, then mayst succour me.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: I am assured to be exempt from woe.
This plot will work my certain overthrow.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I will bear hence thy mother, and my wife,
Untimely murthered with true sorrows knife.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Untimely murthered, happy was that grief,
Which hath abridged whole numbers, numberless:
Of heart surcharging deplorations.
She shall have due and christian funeral,
And rest in peace amongst her ancestors,
As for our bodies, they shall be interred,
In ravening maws, of Ravens, Puttocks, Crows,
Of tattling Magpies, and deaths harbingers,
That will be glutted with wind shaken limbs,
Of blood delighting hateful murtherers:
And yet these many winged sepulchres,
Shall turn to earth, so I, and father shall,
At last attain to earth by funeral,
Well I will prosecute my policy,
That wished death may end my miseries.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Still in your dumps, good Harry yet at last,
Utter your motive of this heaviness:
Why go you not unto your masters house?
What are you parted? if that be the cause,
I will provide you of a better place.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Who roves all day, at length may hit the mark,
That is the cause, because I cannot stay,
With him whose love, is dearer than my life.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Why fell you out? why did you part so soon?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: We fell not out, but fear hath parted us.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: What did he fear your truth or honest life?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: No, no, your understanding is but dim,
That far removed, cannot judge the fear.
We both were fearful, and we both did part,
Because indeed we both were timorous.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: What accident begot your mutual fear?

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: That which my heart hath promised to conceal.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Why now you fall into your ancient vain.

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: It is vain to urge me from this silent vain,
I will conceal it, though it breed my pain.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: It seems to be a thing of consequence,
And therefore prithee Harry for my love,
Open this close fast clasped mystery.

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: Were I assured my heart should have release,
Of secret torment, and distemperature,
I would reveal it to you specially,
Whom I have found my faithful favourite.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Good Harrie Williams make no doubt of that,
Besides, your grief revealed may have relief,
Beyond your present expectation:
Then tell it Harry, what so ever it be,
And ease your heart of horror, me of doubt.

sp.speaker: UUil.
sp.l: What have you heard of Beech of Lambert hill?
And of his boy which late were murthered.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: I heard, and saw, their mangled carcasses.

sp.speaker: UUil.
sp.l: But have you heard of them that murthered them?

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: No, would I had, for then I would blaze their shame,
And make them pay due penance for their sin.

sp.speaker: UUil.
sp.l: This I misdoubteth, therefore will forbear,
To utter what I thought to have revealed.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Knowest thou the actors of this murderous deed,
And wilt conceal it now the deed is done?
Alas poor man, thou knowest not what thou dost,
Thou hast incurred the danger of the law,
And thou amongst them must suffer punishment,
Unless thou do confess it presently.

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: What? shall I then betray my masters life?

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Better than hazard both thy life and soul,
To bolster out such barbarous villainy.
Why then belike your master did the deed.

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: My master unawares escaped my mouth,
But what the Lord doth please shall come to light,
Cannot be hid by human policy:
His hapless hand hath wrought the fatal end,
Of Robert Beech and Thomas Winchester.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: Could he alone do both those men to death?
Hadst thou no share in execution?

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: Nor knew not of it, till the deed was done.

sp.speaker: Cow.
sp.l: If this be true, thou mayst escape with life;
Confess the truth unto the officers,
And thou shalt find the favour of the law.

sp.speaker: VVil.
sp.l: If I offended, it was my Masters love,
That made me hide his great transgressions:
But I will be directed as you please,
So save me God, as I am innocent.

body.stage: Enter Alenso in Falleriaes apparrell and herd, Falleria shauen in shepheards habilliments.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Part of myself, now seemest thou wholly me,
And I seem neither like myself, nor thee:
Thanks to thy care, and this unknown disguise.
I like a shepherd now must learn to know,
When to lead forth my little bleating flock,
To pleasing pastures, and well fatting walks,
In stormy time to drive them to the lee,
To cheer the pretty Lambs, whose bleating voice,
Doth crave the wished comfort of their dams,
To sound my merry Bag-pipe on the downs,
In shearing times poor shepherds festivals,
And lastly, how to drive the Wolf away,
That seek to make the little Lambs their pray.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Ah have you care to drive the Wolf away,
From silly creatures wanting intellect,
And yet would suffer your devouring thoughts,
To suck the blood of your dead brothers son,
As pure and innocent as any lamb,
Pertillo was, which you have fed upon,
But things past help may better be bewailed
With careful tears, than find a remedy,
Therefore for fear our practise be espied,
Let us to question of our husbandry,
How many Lambs fell from the middle flock,
Since I myself did take the latter view.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Some five and twenty, whereof two are dead,
But three and twenty scud about the fields,
That glads my heart to see their jollity.

sp.speaker: Vesu.
sp.l: This is the man, conferring of his Lambs,
That slew a Lamb worth all his flock besides.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: When is the time to let the Weathers blood,
The forward spring, that had such store of grass,
Hath filled them full of rank unwholesome blood,
Which must be purged, else when the winter comes,
The rot will leave me nothing but their skins.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I will let om blood, but yet it is no time,
Until the zygne be gone below the heart.

sp.speaker: Vesu.
sp.l: Forbear a while this idle business,
And talk of matters of more consequence.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I tell you plain, you are no honest man,
To call a shepherd's care an idle toy,
What though we have a little merry sport,
With flowery garlands, and an Oaten pipe,
And jolly frisking on a holly-day,
Yet is a shepherd's cure, a greater cark,
Than sweating Plough-men with their busy work.

sp.speaker: Vesu.
sp.l: Hence leave your sheepish ceremonial,
And now Fallerio, in the Princes name,
I do arrest you, for the cruel murther
Of young Pertillo left unto your charge,
Which you discharged with a bloody writ,
Signed by the hands of those you did suborn:
Nay look not strange, we have such evidence,
To ratify your Stygian cruelty,
That cannot be deluded any way:

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Alas my Lords, I know not what you say,
As for my Nephew, he I hope is well,
I sent him yesterday to Padua.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Aye, he is well, in such an avenger's hands,
As will not wink at your iniquity.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: By heaven and earth my soul is innocent,
Say what you will, I know my conscience.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: To be afflicted with a scourge of care,
Which my over-weaning rashness did inflict.

sp.speaker: Turq.
sp.l: Come bear him hence, expostulate no more,
That heart that could invent such treachery,
Can teach his face to brave it cunningly.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: I do defy your accusations,
Let me have justice I will answer it.

sp.speaker: Vesuu.
sp.l: So bear him hence, I mean to stay behind,
To take possession of his goods and lands:
For the Dukes use, it is too manifest.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: I hope you will answer anything you do,
My Lord Vesuuio you shall answer it:
And all the rest that use extremities.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Aye to the Dukes Exchequer not to you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Thus shades are caught when substances are fled,
Indeed they have my garments, but myself,
Am close enough from their discovery,
But not so close but that my very soul,
Is racked with torments for Pertillos death;
I am Acteon, I do bear about
My horns of shame and inhumanity,
My thoughts, like hounds which late did flatter me:
With hope of great succeeding benefits.
Now gin to tear my care-tormented heart,
With fear of death and torturing punishment,
These are the stings when as our consciences,
Are stuffed and clogged with close concealed crimes,
Well I must smoother all these discontents,
And strive to bear a smoother countenance:
Than rugged care would willingly permit,
I will to the Court to see Allenso free,
That he may then relieve my poverty.

body.stage: Enter Constable, three watchmen with Halberdes.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Who would have thought of all the men alive,
That Thomas Merry would have done this deed:
So full of ruth and monstrous wickedness.

sp.speaker: 1. wat.
sp.l: Of all the men that live in London walls.
I would have thought that Merry had been free,

sp.speaker: 2. wat.
sp.l: Is this the fruits of Saint-like Puritans,
I never like such damned hypocrisy.

sp.speaker: 3. wat.
sp.l: He would not lose a sermon for a pound,
An oath he thought would rend his jaws in twain,
An idle word did whet Gods vengeance on:
And yet two murthers were not scrupulous,
Such close illusions God will bring to light,
And overthrow the workers with his might.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This is the house, come let us knock at door,
I see a light they are not all in bed:
How now fair maid, is your brother up?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: He is not within sir, would you speak with him?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You do but jest, I knew he is within,
And I must needs go up and speak with him.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: In deed good sir, he is in bed asleep,
And I was loath to trouble him tonight.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Well sister, I am sorry for your sake,
But for your brother, he is known to be
A damned villain and an hypocrite,
Rachell, I charge thee in her highness name,
To go with us to prison presently.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: To prison sir, alas what have I done?

sp.speaker: Con:
sp.l: You know that best, but everyone do know,
You and your brother murthered master Beech,
And his poor boy that dwelt at Lambert hill.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: I murthered, my brother knows that I
Did not consent to either of their deaths.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: That must be tried, where doth your brother lie?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Here in his bed, methinks he is not asleep.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Now master Merry, are you in a sweat.

sp.speaker: Merry
sp.l: No verily, I am not in a sweat.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Some sudden fear affrights you, what is the cause?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nothing but that you waked me unawares.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: In the Queens name I do command you rise,
And presently to go along with us.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: With all my heart, what do you know the cause?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: We partly do, when saw you master Beech?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I do not well remember who you mean.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Not Beech the chandler upon Lambert hill.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I know the man, but saw him not this fortnight.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I would you had not, for your sisters sake,
For yours, for his, and for his harmless boy,
Be not obdurate in your wickedness,
Confession draws repentance after it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Well master Constable I do confess,
I was the man that did them both to death:
As for my sister and my harmless man,
I do protest they both are innocent.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Your man is fast in hold, and hath confessed,
The manner how, and where, the deed was done:
Therefore it were vain to colour anything,
Bring them away.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Ah brother woe is me,

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I comfortless will help to comfort thee.

sp.speaker: Trueth
sp.l: Weep, weep poor souls, and interchange your woes,
Now Merry change thy name and countenance:
Smile not, thou wretched creature, lest in scorn,
Thou smile to think on thy extremities,
Thy woes were countless for thy wicked deeds,
Thy sisters death need not increase the count,
For thou couldst never number them before:
Gentles help out with this suppose I pray,
And think it truth for Truth doth tell the tale.
Merry by law convict, as principal,
Receives his doom, to hang till he be dead,
And afterwards for to be hanged in chains:
Williams and Rachell likewise are convict
For their concealment, Williams craves his book,
And so receives a brand of infamy.
But wretched Rachels sex denies that grace,
And therefore doth receive a doom of death,
To die with him, whose sins she did conceal.
Your eyes shall witness of their shaded tipes,
Which many here did see performed indeed:
As for Fallerio, not his homely weeds,
His beardless face, nor counterfeited speech,
Can shield him from deserved punishment:
But what he thinks shall rid him from suspect,
Shall drench him in more waves of wretchedness,
Pulling his son into relentless jaws,
Of hungry death, on tree of infamy:
Here comes the Duke that dooms them both to die,
Next Merries death shall end this Tragedy.

body.stage: Enter Duke, Vesuuio, Turq. Alberto: and Fallerio disguised.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Where is that Syren, that incarnate fiend,
Monster of Nature, spectacle of shame,
Blot and confusion of his family,
False seeming semblance of true-dealing trust,
I mean Fallerio bloody murtherer:
Hath he confessed his cursed treachery,
Or will he stand to prove his innocence.

sp.speaker: Vesu.
sp.l: We have attached Fallerio gracious Lord,
And did accuse him with Pertillos death:
But he remote, will not confess himself,
Neither the means, nor author of the same,
His mighty vows and protestations,
Do almost seem to plead integrity,
But that we all do know the contrary.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I know your error strikes your knowledge blind,
His seeming me, doth so delude your mind.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then bring him forth, to answer for himself,
Since he stands stoutly to deny the deed:
His son can witness, that the dying man,
Accused Fallerio for his treachery,
Stand forth thou close disguised hypocrite,
And speak directly to these articles,
First, didst thou hire two bloody murtherers
To massacre Pertillo in a wood?

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: I never did suborn such murtherers,
But ever loved Pertillo as my life.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thy son can witness to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: I have no son to testify so much.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: No, for his gravity is counterfeit,
Pluck off his beard, and you will swear it so.

sp.speaker: Vesu.
sp.l: Have you no son? doth not Alenso live?

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: Alenso lives, but is no son of mine.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Indeed his better part had not his source,
From thy corrupted vice affecting heart,
For virtue is the mark he aimeth at.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I dare be sworn that Sostrata would blush,
Shouldest thou deny Alenso for thy son.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: Nay did she live, she would not challenge me,
To be the father of that hapless son.

sp.speaker: Turq.
sp.l: Nay, then anon you will deny yourself,
To be yourself, unjust Fallerio.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: I do confess myself, to be myself,
But will not answer to Fallerio.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Not to Fallerio, this is excellent,
You are the man was called Fallerio.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: He never breathed yet that called me so,
Except he were deceived as you are now.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This impudence shall not excuse your fault,
You are well known to be Fallerio,
The wicked husband of dead Sostrata,
And father to the virtuous Alenso,
And even as sure as all these certainties,
Thou didst contrive thy little Nephews death.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: True, for I am nor false Fallerio,
Husband, nor father, as you do suggest,
And therefore did not hire the murtherers:
Which to be true acknowledge with your eyes.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How now my Lords, this is a miracle,
To shake off thirty years so suddenly,
And turn from feeble age to flourishing youth.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: But he my Lord that wrought this miracle,
Is not of power to free himself from death,
Through the performance of this sudden change.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No, were he the chiefest hope of Christendom,
He should not live for this presumption:
Use no excuse, Alenso for thy life,
My doom of death shall be irrevocable.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: Ill fare his soul, that would extenuate
The rigour of your life confounding doom:
I am prepared with all my heart to die,
For that is the end of human misery.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then thus, you shall be hanged immediately,
For your illusion of the Magistrates,
With borrowed shapes of false antiquity.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: Thrice happy sentence, which I do embrace,
With a more fervent and unfeigned zeal,
Than an ambitious rule desiring man,
Would do a Gem bedecked Diadem,
Which brings more watchful cares and discontent,
Than pomp, or honour, can remunerate:
When I am dead, let it be said of me,
Alenso died to set his father free.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: That were a freedom worse than servitude,
To cruel Turk, or damned Infidel:
Most righteous Judge, I do appeal for Justice,
Justice on him that hath deserved death,
Not on Alenso, he is innocent.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: But I am guilty of abetting him,
Contrary to his Majesties Edict,
And therefore death is meritorious.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I am the wretch that did suborn the slaves,
To murther poor Pertillo in the wood,
Spare, spare, Alenso, he is innocent.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What strange appeal is this, we know thee not,
None but Fallerio is accused hereof.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: Then father get you hence, depart in time,
Lest being known you suffer for the crime.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Depart, and leave thee clad in horrors cloak,
And suffer death for true affection:
Although my soul be guilty of more sin,
Than ever sinful soul were guilty of:
Yet fiends of hell would never suffer this,
I am thy father, though unworthy so:
O still I see these weeds do sear your eyes:
I am Fallerio, make no doubt of me.
Though thus disguised, in habit, countenance,
Only to scape the terror of the law.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: And I Alenso that did succour him,
Against your commandment, mighty Sovereign:
Ponder your oath, your vow, as God did live,
I should not live, if I did rescue him:
I did, God lives, and will revenge it home,
If you defer my condign punishment.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Assure yourselves you both shall suffer death:
But for Fallerio, he shall hang in chains,
After he is dead, for he was principal.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Unsavoury Wormwood, Hemlock, bitter gall,
Brings no such bad, unrelished, sour taste,
Unto the tongue, as this death boding voice,
Brings to the ears of poor Fallerio.
Not for myself but for Allensoes sake,
Whom I have murthered by my treachery:
Ah my dread Lord, if any little spark,
Of melting pity doth remain alive,
And not extinguished by my impious deeds,
O kindle it unto a happy flame,
To light Allenso from this misery;
Which through dim death he is like to fall into.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: That were to overthrow my soul and all,
Should you reverse this sentence of my death:
Myself would play the death man on myself,
And overtake your swift and winged soul,
Ere churlish Caron had transported you,
Unto the fields of sad Proserpina.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Cease, cease Fallerio, in thy bootless prayers,
I am resolved, I am inexorable,
Uesuuio, see their judgment be performed,
And use Alenso with all clemency:
Provided that the law be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Vesu.
sp.l: It shall be done with all respectfulness,
Have you no doubt of that my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Here is a mercy mixed with equity,
To show him favour, but cut off his head.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: My reverend father, pacify yourself,
I can, and will, endure the stroke of death,
Were his appearance never so horrible,
To meet Pertillo in another world.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Thou shouldest have tarried until natures course
Had been extinct, that thou overgrown with age,
Mightst die the death of thy progenitors,
It was not thy means he died so suddenly,
But mine, that causing his, have murdered thee.

sp.speaker: Alen.
sp.l: But yet I slew my mother, did I not?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Aye, with reporting of my villainy,
The very audit of my wickedness,
Had force enough to give a sudden death:
Ah sister, sister, now I call to mind,
Thy dying words now proved a prophecy,
If you deal ill with this distressed child:
God will no doubt revenge the innocent,
I have dealt ill, and God hath taken revenge.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Now let us leave remembrance of past deeds,
And think on that which more concerneth us.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: With all my heart thou ever wert the spur,
Which pricked me on to any godliness:
And now thou dost endeavour to incite,
Me make my parting peace with God and men:
I do confess even from my very soul,
My heinous sin and grievous wickedness,
Against my maker many thousand ways:
Abimo cordis I repent myself,
Of all my sins against his majesty:
And heavenly father lay not to my charge,
The death of poor Pertillo and those men,
Which I suborned to be his murtherers,
When I appear before thy heavenly throne,
To have my sentence, or of life or death.

sp.speaker: Uesu.
sp.l: Amen, amen, and God continue still,
These mercy moving meditations.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: And thou great God which art omnipotent,
Powerful enough for to redeem our souls:
Even from the very gates of gaping hell,
Forgive our sins, and wash away our faults;
In the sweet river of that precious blood,
Which thy dear son did shed in Galgotha,
For the remission of all contrite souls.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Forgive thy death my thrice beloved son.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: I do, and father pardon my misdeeds,
Of disobedience and unthankfulness.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Thou never yet wert disobedient,
Unless I did command unlawfulness,
Ungratefulness did never trouble thee,
Thou art too bounteous thus to guerdon me.

sp.speaker: Allen.
sp.l: Come let us kiss and thus embrace in death,
Even when you will come bring us to the place:
Where we may consummate our wretchedness,
And change it for eternal happiness.

body.stage: Enter Merry and Rachel to execution with Officers with Halberdes, the Hangman with a lather. etc.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Now sister Rachell is the hour come,
Wherein we both must satisfy the law,
For Beeches death and harmless Winchester:
Weep not sweet sister, for that cannot help,
I do confess fore all this company,
That thou wert never privy to their deaths,
But only helpest me when the deed was done,
To wipe the blood and hide away my sin,
And since this fault hath brought thee to this shame,
I do entreat thee on my bended knee,
To pardon me for thus offending thee.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: I do forgive you from my very soul,
And think not that I shed these store of tears,
For that I price my life, or fear to die,
Though I confess the manner of my death,
Is much more grievous than my death itself;
But I lament for that it hath been said,
I was the author of this cruelty,
And did produce you to this wicked deed,
Whereof God knows that I am innocent.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Indeed thou art, thy conscience is at peace,
And feels no terror for such wickedness,
Mine hath been vexed but is now at rest,
For that I am assured my heinous sin:
Shall never rise in judgment against my soul,
But that the blood of Jesus Christ hath power,
To make my purple sin as white as Snow.
One thing good people, witness here with me,
That I do die in perfect charity,
And do forgive, as I would be forgiven,
First of my God, and then of all the world:
Cease publishing that I have been a man,
Trained up in murther, or in cruelty,
For fore this time, this time is all too soon,
I never slew or did consent to kill,
So help me God as this I speak is true:
I could say something of my innocence,
In fornication and adultery,
But I confess the justest man alive
That bears about the frailty of a man,
Cannot excuse himself from daily sin,
In thought, in word, and deed, such was my life,
I never hated Beech in all my life,
Only desire of money which he had,
And the inciting of that foe of man,
That greedy gulf, that great Lauiathan,
Did hall me on to these calamities,
For which, even now my very soul doth bleed:
God strengthen me with patience to endure,
This chastisement, which I confess too small
A punishment for this my heinous sin:
O be courageous sister, fight it well,
We shall be crowned with immortality.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: I will not faint, but combat manfully,
Christ is of power to help and strengthen me.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: I pray make haste, the hour is almost past.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I am prepared, O God receive my soul,
Forgive my sins, for they are numberless,
Receive me God, for now I come to thee.

body.stage: Turne of the Lather: Rachel shrinketh.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Nay shrink not woman, have a cheerful heart.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Aye, so I do, and yet this sinful flesh,
Will be rebellious against my willing spirit.
Come let me clime these steps that lead to heaven,
Although they seem the stairs of infamy:
Let me be mirror to ensuing times,
And teach all sisters how they do conceal,
The wicked deeds, of brethren, or of friends,
I not repent me of my love to him,
But that thereby I have provoked God,
To heavy wrath and indignation,
Which turn away great God, for Christ's sake.
Ah Harry Williams, thou wert chiefest cause,
That I do drink of this most bitter cup,
For hadst thou opened Beeches death at first,
The boy had lived, and thou hadst saved my life:
But thou art branded with a mark of shame,
And I forgive thee from my very soul,
Let him and me, learn all that hear of this,
To utter brothers or their masters miss,
Conceal no murther, lest it do beget,
More bloody deeds of like deformity.
Thus God forgive my sins, receive my soul,
And though my dinner be of bitter death,
I hope my soul shall sup with Jesus Christ,
And see his presence everlastingly.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: The Lord of heaven have mercy on her soul,
And teach all other by this spectacle,
To shun such dangers as she ran into,
By her misguided taciturnity:
Cut down their bodies, give hers funeral,
But let his body be conveyed hence,
To Mile-end green, and there be hanged in chains.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: See here the end of lucre and desire
Of riches, gotten by unlawful means,
What monstrous evils this hath brought to pass,
Your scarce dry eyes give testimonial,
The father, son; the sister, brother brings,
To open scandal, and contemptuous death.
But here come they that wrought these deeds of ruth,
As if they meant to plot new wickedness:
Whether so fast, you damned miscreants?
Ye vain deluders of the credulous,
That seek to train men to destruction.

sp.speaker: Mur.
sp.l: Why we will on, to set more harms afloat,
That I may swim in rivers of warm blood,
Out-flowing from the sides of Innocents.

sp.speaker: Coue.
sp.l: I will entice the greedy minded soul,
To pull the fruit from the forbidden tree:
Yet Tantall like, he shall but glut his eye,
Nor feed his body with salubrious fruit,

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Hence Stigmatics, you shall not harbour here;
To practice execrable butcheries:
Myself will bring your close designs to light,
And overthrow your vild conspiracies,
No heart shall entertain a murderous thought,
Within the sea embracing continent,
Where fair Eliza Prince of piety,
Doth wear the peace adorned Diadem.

sp.speaker: Coue.
sp.l: Maugre the worst, I will have many hearts,
That shall affect my secret whisperings,
The chink of gold is such a pleasing cry,
That all men wish to hear such harmony,
And I will place stern murther by my side,
That we may do more harms, than haughty pride.

sp.speaker: Homi.
sp.l: Truth, now farewell, hereafter thou shalt see,
I will vex thee more with many tragedies.

sp.speaker: Truth.
sp.l: The more the pity, would the heart of man,
Were not so open wide to entertain,
The harmful baits, of self devouring sin,
But from the first unto the latter times,
It hath and will be so eternally,
Now it remains to have your good advice,
Unto a motion of some consequence,
There is a Bark that newly rigged for sea,
Unmanned, unfurnished with munition:
She must encounter with a greater foe,
Than great Alcydes slew in Lerna Lake,
Would you be pleased to man this willing bark,
With good conceits of her intention,
To store her with the thundering furniture,
Of smoothest smiles, and pleasing plaudits,
She shall be able to endure the shock,
Of snarling Zoylus, and his cursed crew,
That seeks to sink her in reproaches waves,
And may perchance obtain a victory,
Against curious carps, and fawning Parasites:
But if you suffer her for want of aid,
To be overwhelmed by her insulting foes,
O then she sinks, that meant to pass the flood,
With stronger force to do her country good:
It resteth thus, whether she live or die,
She is your Beadsman everlastingly.
